title: Talking Heads Made Their First Music Video In 32 Years With Saoirse Ronan and Legendary Director Mike Mills
article_text: This is an edition of the newsletterPulling Weeds With Chris Black,in which the columnist weighs in on hot topics in culture.Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Thursday. Mike Mills has one of the most envy-inducing creative careers that I've been lucky enough to witness. He has done it all—from artwork and graphic design forSupreme, Beck, X-Girl, and Sonic Youth to music videos for Air, Pulp, andThe National. He has directed several beloved and critically acclaimed films, includingBeginners,20th Century Women, andC'mon C'mon. For more than two decades, Mills has been collaborating with the best musicians and actors on the planet, so I wasn’t stunned to find out that he directed the first-ever music video forTalking Heads’ classic tune “Psycho Killer,” starring Saoirse Ronan, to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the band’s first gig (at CBGB, of course, opening for the Ramones.) I spoke to Mike from his home in Los Angeles about his first musical memory, dumb music videos, skipping film school, andFrank Ocean. GQ:I was just talking to a friend about the “Psycho Killer” video. He told me that his dad listened to the cassette and it was his first musical memory. Mike Mills:I don't know what mine is. I remember I was trying to be in a punk band, and I barely knew what music was, and my sister had [Fleetwood Mac’s]Rumoursrecord around. I listened toRumoursto try to figure out what a verse and a chorus was. What a beautiful, complicated record to try to learn how to make the most destructive music we could make. It's funny, I have such a connection to Talking Heads. Again, my sister introduced me to it. It's really one of those records that hit right at the right time and changed my life. By working on the video, I found that everyone has a Talking Heads story. Saoirse played “This Must Be the Place” at her wedding. Every crew member has one, my parents— we all have some crazy personal Talking Heads thing. It made me trip out. Like, What's their life? It must be weird being the Talking Heads. Did the idea come from you? Did you write a treatment? There was no idea. I have a little bit of connection with David, but I competed. There were other directors writing treatments. When I first got the email, I was like, "Fuck, of course, someone else is going to get this.” It's fucking Psycho Killer, how the fuck do you do a video treatment for that song? It's too good. It's too classic. I was really in that mood, a “goddammit" kind of mood. Then it just came in full form, like “Boop!” This pattern of repeating life and repeating moments and shooting each moment exactly the same way, but hyper-ing the feelings— doing them in this intense way. It was one of those little gifts I have no good story for. It was on the way to the bathroom, I had the idea. The video's great. It speaks to the song without being heavy-handed. I was talking to a friend yesterday who's a director, and I asked him why labels still pay for music videos, and he said that YouTube's the biggest thing, and that's where people see everything now. It's almost come full circle from MTV. It’s not only where people see things, it's where peoplehearthings. If I was a musician right now, I'd be like, “That's a bummer.” But as a director, it's kind of interesting. Do you watch YouTube? Are you on it? My kid is, and we're very tight around music. We share a lot. Inadvertently I am, but I like music without visuals. Music's so important to me. It’s such a medicine or such a spiritual doorway. It's what got me into making art. That being said, they have this amazing relationship because they're both time-based arts. And the more I work on it, the more I realize that's the thing about both music and film. It's dealing with time, and time is such a fucked up situation for humans, always going by and we can't grab onto it. Both are ways of playing with it. To me, all filmmaking is trying to be like music. It’s trying to have that same somatic feeling delivery vehicle that music has with the same kind of flow and unpredictability. I'm always chasing music when I do visuals. I'm a wannabe musician, I picked up the next best thing, which was directing. I became a filmmaker making music videos. I didn't go to film school, I made videos. That, andKim's Video. That was my film school. I would love to do more videos, but they don’t come around very often. Having just sort of dissed music videos, I fucking love them. They're so fun. It's a freer space. In like 99% of my videos, the band wasn’t in the video. That was always the coolest way to do it. And I know the record label would fight hard on that. But sometimes it's great. I did a video forPulp, and it's just Jarvis Cocker, wall-to-wall. It’s like, "Well, yeah." That's all you need! "This is the best thing in the world." How do you say “cut” to him? But it's a sacred space for me, music videos. I can remember a few moments of importance, like the last time we gathered around the computer to watch a music video. It was “Bad Girls,” the M.I.A. video where they were ghost riding the cars in the Middle East. It had been long enough where people weren't spending money like that. It looked like such a big production and it really stopped us in our tracks. Yeah, it's funny, my kid is really getting into “Paper Planes” and M.I.A. That's a musician where the whole package is their art. I feel like all bands, all musicians, should have to do their first record cover and the first video on their own. So you're like, “This is who this person is.” You can't hide behind someone else's taste. I want to know their whole deal. The videos I've been watching lately are likethe Kendrick [Lamar] oneswhere you think, “okay, what is going on? What piece of conceptual art did he just present?” There's a depth and a rigor to them that you could do a podcast about. It’s not just, “Let's have someone dance around some cool lights.” The thing is that I like both. I'm down for something to be good and not have any meaning. I'm with you. Sometimes I'm all in on fanning out and just watching someone look good. That's sort of what music videos are built on. I went the other way. I started out trying to be Michel Gondry or something. Like, “It has to be a conceptual piece of art.” Also, I'm a frustrated feature filmmaker not getting to make films, so I'm trying to put all that energy into a music video, plus I come from conceptual art school, so I'm treating it that way. Now, finally, I can relax and have a Popsicle and just watch a dumb video like, "That's cool. I'm in." I think because we’re also just paralyzed by choice all the time, especially with TV and film. There are people who like dumb stuff and people who like intellectual stuff. I prefer dumb stuff for certain things and smart stuff when it comes to other mediums. Like when a TV show gets insane reviews and generates breathless conversation online, it turns me off. I don't care anymore. So I won't watchSuccession, I’ll watchReal Housewives. That's just who I am. That's funny. Lately I just wormhole in the past, now that you can do it so easily. Because for my generation, when there was a new record out, you had to walk to someone's house and knock on the door and go like, "Do you have the Adolescents record? Because I heard it's out…” Going back to the Talking Heads, that wholeRemain In Lighttour, you can watch every city and see the whole concert. It makes me, like, teeth-grittingly want to be there. I want the time machine to work. My preferred genre is late-night TV performances. That's what I find myself coming back to. It's almost a music video in its own way. For sure. I just went to the Grand National Tour, the Kendrick/SZA tour. It’s like all these mega tours now, it’s really impressive. It's like watching a video being made. There's 35 dancers, it's very choreographed, there are eight cameras. It's just a crazy shoot. It's a shoot in front of 50,000 people. 100 percent. It's a full production every night. And when it gets that big, it has to be. Not only are there 35 dancers, but they do five wardrobe changes, so there's a whole wardrobe department. They do hair and makeup. They have a whole camera crew. It's like a traveling city of a production. It takes an army. I want to do that. If someone's seeing this, I want that job. You could definitely do it. I know people who have done it. The touring part is usually what people won’t do. They're happy to direct it, but if you have to direct it every night… I never saw what Spike did withFrank Ocean, but everyone loved it. I'm not a big Frank Ocean fan, but it was very cool. What?! How can you not—? Frank Ocean is one of the most overrated artists that we've ever encountered. Everything about it is presented very well, the vibe is good, it sounds really good, but sinceChannel Orange, there are no songs that I want to listen to. I could listen toBlondeevery day, all day. I tried and it just wasn’t for me. You're like, "No.Real Housewives. Turn it back on!”

title: 16 Best Summer Blazers for Men in 2025, According to GQ
article_text: All products featured on GQ are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. Despite what you may think, the best summer blazers are more than just an easy fix for your mid-Julywedding styleobligations or your return-to-office woes (thoughts and prayers!). A great summer blazer lets you remix everything in your closet: add one, andT-shirtsget tonier,shortsget sharper, drapey linen pants get sexier. Though yes, ofcoursea perfect warm-weather sport coat will crush when you’re out in Clearwater for thebeach weddingof that second cousin you haven’t seen since you both thought Axe body spray was cologne. That’s because a summer blazer does what your three-season wool suits and tweedy sport coats cannot: breathe. When you’re dealing with a swelteranda dress code, ventilation is the only thing that matters. In pulling together our favorite summer blazers, we broke them down by fabrics: airy, open linen; crisp and sturdy cotton; loose and limber tropical wool, and puckered seersucker. Most are either half-lined or completely unlined—because that’s one less layer between you and the gentle breeze keeping your lower back from feeling like the Everglades. Below, 16 summer blazers that will immediately upgrade the rest of your outfit, helping you look and feel as cool as the cocktail in your hand. Linen’s made a big comeback as the tailoring pendulum swings once again toward loose and leisurely, and we couldn’t be happier. It’s made from flax, a natural fiber with a signature crispness—which also makes it prone to wrinkles. A quick steam should bring everything back to normal, but don’t pay them any mind while you’re out and about. Todd Snyder Todd Snyder Once again,Todd Snyderproves you can add flair to a jacket without sacrificing function. With its natural shoulders, double vents, and a beautiful glen plaid check woven from a cooling combo of linen and silk, this blazer practically books your next Italian getaway for you. Alex Mill Alex Mill We wouldn’t want to wear a dark color while sitting in the blazing sun, but in any other scenario, a fluttery double-breasted summer blazer made of 100 percent linen works its charms. Particularly if that scenario is a coastal European vacation calling for a one-jacket solution to cover relaxed days and wine-filled nights. Corridor Saks Fifth Avenue Corridor's blazer skews a little toward achore coat, with linen’s texture and that olive color adding to the rustic look. Which just means that it’ll stand proud when you dress it up, but hang loose with a tee and off-white jeans. Natalino Natalino London-based Natalino makes some of the best Italian-made blazers in the biz. Everything about this one is ultra laid back; from the natural shoulder and high armhole to the elegant drape, it makes us want to shout “che bella” at everyone we meet. Like linen, but not the wrinkles. Try seersucker, it’s southern-accented friend. Whether you’re sipping sweet tea on a sun-blasted porch or wrapping up 18 holes at the country club, the fabric’s puckered texture keeps it from sticking to skin or getting creased. Chuck it in your carry-on—or better yet, just wear it on the plane—and you’ll be set for weddings, garden parties, bayou crawfish boils, and anything else that comes your way. Sid Mashburn Sid Mashburn No surprise that legendary southern gentlemanSid Mashburnmakes beautiful seersucker pieces. This jacket’s softly-structured shape and throwback stripes deserve to be at the Kentucky Derby (the stands, not the infield). Flint and Tinder Huckberry Flint and Tinder has expanded from basics into higher-difficulty stuff likewaxed canvas coatsand this dialed-in seersucker blazer. The tonal stripes make the whole affair a little more debonair, while a teensy bit of stretch means this blazer will groove with you on the dance floor. Buck Mason Buck Mason We’ve been on the record asbig believers in Buck Mason’s nicely-priced Carry-On Jacket, and the seersucker version is no exception. A barely-there five-ounce blazer that can do it all, with the option to grab matching pants for only $228 more? This is what our great-grandfathers fought for. Stòffa Stòffa Stòffa��’s relaxed, almost loungewear-like suiting is made better by the fact that the brand chooses the best colors in menswear. Chocolate wool seersucker? Can’t say we’ve seen it before; can’t stop thinking about it since we did. Cotton’s got the range—from crisp poplin to textured twill, brushed moleskin, and garment-dyed canvas—to hold down a summer jacket collection just by itself. It helps that cotton tends to be fairly casual and fairly easy to care for, too. You could wear a cotton blazer six days a week, toss it in the wash on Sunday, air dry it, and start all over again Monday morning. Madewell Madewell A cotton-nylon blazer will keep you cool—and, frankly, we like the soft wrinkles that add a little texture. Even better, Madewell’s version will leave a few extra bucks in your pocket, since it’s on sale. Mr P. Mr Porter Mr Porter’s in-house label aced the test again with this cotton-linen blend jacket that’s been garment dyed. The higher cut of the lapels and lack of vents in the back make it a little more chill than a stuffier blazer, too. Knickerbocker Huckberry Knickerbocker had some fun with the quintessential hopsack jacket by cooking it up in cotton-twill and taking up some solid real estate with a trio of squared-off pockets. This jacket should absolutely stay in your rotation all the way through summer and into pumpkin spice season. De Bonne Facture Mr Porter Parisian label De Bonne Facture’s jacket is made totravel—and maybe start an art movement along the way. Inspired by the Union des Artistes Modernes (an association of architects, decorators, painters, and photographers), it brings a wider lapel and a boxy fit looks even better with a vintage Leica dangling from its shoulder. Linen, cotton, and seersucker can see you through most summertime dress-ups, but if the dress code is genuinely formal and the thermometer is rising fast, you’ll want a summer blazer made of tropical wool. Wool is naturally good at wicking moisture, and tropical wool’s open weave is looser and more breathable than traditional wool. With its crisp, matte finish—sometimes with a subtle sheen depending on the weave—it pairs well with a freshdress shirt. So go ahead, suit up for summer without suffering for style. COS COS COShas such tasteful sweaters, bags, jackets, and soft tailoring that it almost feels rudenotto compliment them. Its fluid blazer, for instance, looks like it’s been stolen from a vintage Armani collection thanks to its relaxed shape, notch lapels, and (not-too-aggressively) padded shoulders. Universal Works Huckberry This British brand cooked up a relaxed, navy-colored blazer made for summer: lightweight, stylish, and ready to multitask. It doesn’t mess around, so if you’re after something sharp but low-key for the office or date night (or both), consider this your sartorial wingman. J.Press J.Press A navy blazer with gold buttons is as Ivy as it gets, and who better to nail it in a summer-break-ready tropical wool leans than the legendary J. Press? With crisp khakis and a repp tie, this loose-wearing sack blazer will let ‘em know you’re just biding your time until you take over the family business. Or play it against type with somelooser pantsand a pair of chunkyloafers. Drake's Drake's Admittedly charcoal wouldn’t be our first color choice for a midday sun-soaked event, but Drake’s may have made the platonic ideal of a tropical-weight wool jacket: unlined, soft-shouldered, patch-pocketed and flawlessly shaped. It’s barely-there tailoring done with Savile Row-skill; the kind of jacket that begs to be paired with anoxford shirttucked into your favoritejeans. By now, we've covered the fabric and construction basics, so let’s dig into the finer details that’ll make sure your jacket matches your summer state of mind—relaxed, breezy, and maybe slightly sun-kissed. The fit should be free-breathing:The only thing that makes a summer blazer feel breezy is a breeze. Skip anything too slim or snug. Go for a slightly relaxed fit—not “family CPA” oversized, but roomy enough to let air move through. If the shoulders are even a little bit snug, go up a size. No matter how jacked you are, no one should be able to see the contours of your lats in a summer blazer. Color is key:If you anticipate being outside for any length of time, err on the side of light and bright: khaki, stone, light blue, off-white. A gentle check or stripe works if you’re feeling fun. Details like patch pockets, and soft shoulders are your best friends for a little visual interest. Avoid hot-and-heavy details:While full- or half-canvas linings are often the hallmark of solid suiting, in summer you don’t want anything unnecessary between you and the AC. Synthetic fabrics are also the enemy: they don’t breathe, they trap heat, and theydefinitelydon’t come with a cortisone cream for the itch they bring. Style is subjective, we know—that’s the fun of it. But we’re serious about helping our audience get dressed. Whether it’s thebest white sneakers, the flyest affordable suits, or the need-to-knowmenswear drops of the week, GQ Recommends’ perspective is built on years of hands-on experience, an insider awareness of what’s in and what’s next, and a mission to find the best version of everything out there, at every price point. Our staffers aren’t able to try on every single piece of clothing you read about on GQ.com (fashion moves fast these days), but we have an intimate knowledge of each brand’s strengths and know the hallmarks of quality clothing—from materials and sourcing, to craftsmanship, to sustainability efforts that aren’t just greenwashing. GQ Recommends heavily emphasizes our own editorial experience with those brands, how they make their clothes, and how those clothes have been reviewed by customers. Bottom line: GQ wouldn’t tell you to wear it if we wouldn’t. We make every effort to cast as wide of a net as possible, with an eye on identifying the best options across three key categories:quality,fit, andprice. To kick off the process, we enlist the GQ Recommends braintrust to vote on our contenders. Some of the folks involved have worked in retail, slinging clothes to the masses; others have toiled for small-batch menswear labels; all spend way too much time thinking about what hangs in their closets. We lean on that collective experience to guide our search, culling a mix of household names, indie favorites, and the artisanal imprints on the bleeding-edge of the genre. Then we narrow down the assortment to the picks that scored the highest across quality, fit, and price. Across the majority of our buying guides, our team boasts firsthand experience with the bulk of our selects, but a handful are totally new to us. So after several months of intense debate, we tally the votes, collate the anecdotal evidence, and emerge with a list of what we believe to be the absolute best of the category right now, from the tried-and-true stalwarts to the modern disruptors, the affordable beaters to the wildly expensive (but wildly worth-it) designer riffs. Whatever your preferences, whatever your style, there's bound to be a superlative version on this list for you. (Read more about GQ's testing processhere.)

title: 3 Days in the Utah Desert With Haider Ackermann: ‘I Need This Calmness’
article_text: This is an edition of the newsletterShow Notes,in which Samuel Hine reports from the front row of the fashion world.Sign up here to get it free. Haider Ackermann understands why people were surprised when he wasappointedcreative director of Canada Goose in May of last year. “It was not aligned with my road,” he suggested recently. At the time,Ackermann—king of raffish, worldly menswear, Timotheé Chalamet’s best pal andpersonal tailor—was on the short list for seemingly every luxury house vacancy. He had designed rich cashmere and leather coats during his celebrated stint at Berluti, but never technical outerwear. A recent triumph was in the rarefied arena of couture, when he guest designed an ecstatically received collection for Jean Paul Gaultier. Canada Goose was a curveball. His ultimate direction was confirmed when, a few months after the Canada Goose announcement, Ackermann alsotook the reins of Tom Ford. By which point his new Canada Goose posting started looking more like a side hustle. After all, Ackermann was facing a tall order to successfully reinvent red-carpet-wear at Tom Ford. Could one person, even a designer as inarguably visionary as Ackermann, also hack extreme outdoor gear at the same time? And what did a swashbuckling aesthete who had never before worn a parka (and once passed on the top job at Margiela) see in the role? I followed Ackermann into an endless expanse of sun-baked desert to find out. The fashion press trip is considered a perk by some and a champagne problem by others. Either way, the luxury junket tends to hew to a predictable formula: think adult field trips for editors and influencers through luxury hotels and five-star restaurants, art museums and other local attractions. Ackermann, however, has a much different idea of how to wine and dine the industry, which was apparent well before I stepped off a prop plane on a spit of tarmac straddling the Utah-Arizona border last weekend, where I joined the designer for a three-day, Canada Goose-funded expedition through the remote region’s canyons and lakes. In the weeks leading up to the trip, I was assured that Ackermann had curated the guest list with personal friends rather than the usual suspects. Guests were told to pack light and bring shower shoes. The custom campsite near Bullfrog Basin, Utah Boating on Lake Powell The trip was ostensibly to unveil Ackermann’s new collection forSnow Goose, the elevated Canada Goose sub-line he launched last winter, but from the jump another agenda emerged: to show his crew—which included the models Erin Wasson and Kai Isaiah-Jamal,Systemco-founder Elizabeth von Guttman, artist Jack Pierson, curator Neville Wakefield, stylist Jerry Stafford, British fashion editor Olivia Singer, and tattoo artist to the stars Dr. Woo (i.e. no influencers)—how to vacation Haider-style. We weren’t exactly roughing it. My tent, built on a picturesque bluff where previously there had been nothing but rocks and scrub, was bigger than my bedroom in New York and came with Augustinus Bader sunscreen on the bedside table. There aren’t many designers I would take up on fashion summer camp—even a camp with real showers stocked with Aesop products. But Ackermann’s reputation as a globe-trotting aesthete precedes him. He inherited his sense of adventure from his father, a French cartographer who adopted Ackermann from Colombia. The family moved from the Netherlands across Africa, stopping in Ethiopia, Chad, and Algeria. Vacation meant a trip to the Sahara. The last time I saw him, he was gussied up in a gorgeous tuxedo at histriumphant Tom Ford debutin Paris; in Utah, I was immediately struck by how equally noble he looked in cargo pants. The constant change and his evolving outsider status trained Ackermann’s eye to hold onto moments of beauty. “We lived in so many countries, and because of that you isolate yourself more,” he told me in his gentle, unplaceable accent. “You become the observer.” He’s now known for his exploratory taste in holiday destinations (hiking mountains in Bhutan, overlanding through Namibia, swimming in the Maldives) and iconic companions in wanderlust (Tilda Swinton, Robert Rabensteiner, Waris Ahluwalia). To my surprise—because wherehasn’tAckermann been—Southern Utah was a first. “Utah has always been a dream of mine,” he said. “I always make a point to go to places where I have never been before, and I wanted to have the same intrigued energy and search for beauty as the rest on this expedition.” Perhaps it was the heatwave we landed in, but the days quickly melted into a mirage of extreme aesthetic experiences: boating through the ancient caverns of Lake Powell; dinner in a windy slot canyon accessible only via an off-road ATV trail (with Pierson as my mercifully trusting passenger); a helicopter ride to the top of the majestic, perilously tall Tower Butte; a horseback ride at sunset. At several points, I noticed Ackermann was removed in quiet contemplation while his guests posed for impromptu photo shoots or lounged around gossiping (hallmarks of any press trip, no matter how remote). Ackermann hosting dinner in a slot canyon On the final night, I found the designer sitting outside his tent looking out at a sunset so vivid it would render Cormac McCarthy speechless. He cracked a cold beer and sighed a sigh of profound relaxation. “I need this calmness,” he said. “I mean, you witnessed thefirst Tom Ford moment. It's madness. And trust me, I enjoyed it—but it’s madness. So it's very good sometimes to just step back.” Though the trip was technically work, madness of a different flavor, the hot, languorous days seemed to have recharged Ackermann’s battery pack. “All of this has been very inspiring. I know I'm going to take this with me, whatever brand it's going to be. Perhaps also because my eyes are more open, and I'm more willing to listen.”Why is that?I asked. “Because my weeks are quite strict,” he replied. “The agenda is really harsh and hard. So I'm not very open-minded. I'm just very focused on doing my thing. And perhaps here, this is me taking the time. “I think that I'm working three days for Canada Goose, and four days for Tom Ford,” he added with a smirk. The top of Tower Butte Charlie Knepper wearing Snow Goose Ackermann never really considered doing a fashion show for Snow Goose. “There are already so many of them. So, why?” he said. I asked him how he pitched his corporate bosses on the expedition concept, more logistically complex than any runway productions. “I wanted people to experience or to feel what I felt when I first wore the parka,” he said. That was in Churchill, Manitoba, where Canada Goose works with Polar Bear International to support scientific research and conservation efforts. (“They’ve been supporting Polar Bear International for so many years already, but being very silent about it, which is a rare elegance,” Ackermann noted.) “I suddenly realized how good that piece was, how much it kept you warm, and the luxury of it, even if I don’t like to use that word,” he added. His first press trip, last winter, saw the likes of Evan Mock and Tim Blanks dropped on a glacier in Iceland. “After Iceland, I was sort of like,Oh my God, what am I going to do next?” Ackermann acknowledges that his hiring was a surprise for Canada Goose as well. “It was quite extraordinary—the guts he had to do it,” he said of the brand’s CEO (and third-generation founding family member) Dani Reiss. Unlike Moncler and other upscale outerwear brands, Canada Goose had never made a significant fashion play, and amidst a wider luxury spending downturn, the company’s numbers have defied gravity. Investing in Ackermann was an audacious and potentially risky move. Says Reiss, “Haider brings a bold, visionary perspective to Canada Goose, one that honors our heritage and craftsmanship while authentically pushing creative boundaries.” When I first opened my tent, I found Ackermann’s latest work hanging on a clothing rack: pieces from the Snow Goose spring-summer 2025 collection, which officially drops June 12. (He found the Snow Goose moniker in the brand’s archives from the ’70s.) There was a lightly-padded olive green down bomber with matching scanty short-shorts (leave it to Ackermann to make GORP look Antwerpian and sexy), as well as a set of oversized tees and thick sweats emblazoned with the question “can you hear the birds?” that are surely destined for Timmy’s closet. And lest you think Snow Goose would wither under high UVs, Ackermann created a lightweight parka shell, neon green and shaped with the sharpness you’d expect from the guy also helming the house of Ford. Reiss hails the sophomore collection a “striking expression of our past and our future: thoughtfully designed, globally resonant and tastefully provocative.” Yee-haw! As we watched the sunset, Ackermann suggested that he’s just getting started. “I think it's just the beginning of the story,” he said. “There’s so much we take from Canada Goose, and they have so much to take from me.” For one, there will be more trips. “Trust me, I'm not giving up on these moments. I can't,” he said. (He’s already decided to come back to Utah at some point.) What he’s not planning to do is turn Snow Goose into a fashion brand. “I want to respect and embrace the brand and make it wonderful,” Ackermann told me. “If it becomes a fashion brand, perhaps I'm less intrigued by it.” He has Tom Ford for that. His experience at his other job, he said, has only inspired him to make each brand “more extreme from each other.” Canada Goose, he noted with admiration, is “so functional. And when you do an evening gown for Tom Ford, it's not functional. It's celebrating beauty.” Which is a long way from where he started, as an adventurist who had nonetheless eschewed Gore-Tex parkas for kaftans. What ultimately brought him to Canada Goose, he told me, was the familiar intoxicating force of the unknown: “I had never done outerwear, I had never even worn a parka before. But sometimes it's nice to take roads that are not the most direct ones. The side roads are sometimes the most beautiful.” Sign up for Show Notes to receive my subscriber-only Tip Sheet in your inbox.

title: Here’s Exactly How Much Fat You Should Be Eating a Day
article_text: There may be no nutrient more maligned than fat. In the 90s, it waswidely believedwe needed to avoid fat at all costs, and food products branded as “low-fat” were everywhere. By the 2010s, the pendulum swung the other way: fat was suddenly in. Theketogenic dietentered society’s collective conscious, people started putting butter in their coffee, and avocado toast was a hot brunch item. Cut to today: chances are you still don’t know exactly how much fat — or what kinds — you should be eating. So we consulted registered dietitians and put together this guide as a reference. It covers everything from how much fat per day to consume to the healthiest ways to get it, so you can plan your fitness goals accordingly. First, afat refresher. There arefour types of fatscommonly found in the average diet: Monosaturated fats and polyunsaturated fats are the most beneficial of the group, according to all of the dietitians we spoke to. Registered dietitianKristin Kirkpatrick, M.S., R.D.N., cites a2016JAMAstudythat found that unsaturated fats consumption contributed to a longer life. “These fats have strong clinical evidence to their benefits and are found in a variety of foods such as fatty wild fish, nuts and seeds, extra-virgin and avocado oils,” says Kirkpatrick. One type of polyunsaturated fat,omega-3 fatty acids, is especially beneficial. “Omega-3 fatty acids have been linked tobrainandheart healthand have also shown benefit in multiple trials to mental health as well, mainly depression and anxiety,” she says. What about saturated fats?Michael Reavis Jr., M.S., R.D.., the lead sports dietitian at Fit With Food, says that saturated fats aren’t inherently bad, but he points toscientific researchshowing that too much of it is linked to increasing the risk of cardiovascular disease, as a result of raising LDL cholesterol. That’s why you don’t want to go ham on saturated fats (pun very much intended). Registered dietitianAndy De Santis, R.D. is similarly wary of categorizing saturated fat as “bad” or “unhealthy” because it’s found in foods that are great sources of nutrients, like red meat and eggs. If these foods are part of how you get your protein, you’ll be consuming some saturated fat. As long as you vary your protein sources, he says, you won’t need to focus on trying to meet any saturated fat goals; you’ll be consuming enough already. “Saturated fats do benefit the body, such as by playing a role in hormone formation,” he says. “But the reality is that it’s not a type of fat that is typically underconsumed [by Americans], unlike unsaturated fats.” In total, the amount of fat you should be eating each day should be between 25% and 35% of your daily calories, according to both theAmerican Heart Association and the National Institute of Health. Their recommendations also say that fats and trans fats should be limited to less than 7% and 1% of daily calories, respectively. You should limit your saturated fat consumption to less than 10% of overall daily calories. Reavis says you can modify the AHA and NIH’s recommendations, depending on how active you are. If you’re mostly sedentary, he says to aim for the lower end. If you live an active lifestyle or work out a lot, go for the higher end. Fat intake is a reflection of calorie intake, De Santis adds In other words, if your calorie intake goes up, so does your fat intake. Let’s say you generally eat 2,000 calories a day. With the above guidelines in mind, this means that you should aim for between 40 and 70 grams of monounsaturated fats and polyunsaturated fats a day. (Remember, we’re limiting saturated fats to less than 10% of total calories consumed and taking out trans fats completely, which is why they’re not part of the equation.) What does this look like?One small serving of fishhas roughly five grams of unsaturated fats,half an avocadohas 20 grams of primarily unsaturated fats,an egghas roughly 3.5 grams of unsaturated fat and 1.5 grams of saturated fat, anda serving of macadamia nutshas 70 grams of primarily unsaturated fats. While these guidelines are helpful for most people in terms of figuring out how much fat per day to consume, Kirkpatrick says that it’s important to know that genetics can play a role in how the body processes and stores fat. There is a specific gene, theAPOA2 gene, that can influence how much weight is gained from a diet high in saturated fat. People with certain genetic variants of this gene should be especially careful to minimize saturated fat because they can gain weight easier from a diet that’s high in it. It boils down to this: Aim for fat intake to be between 25% and 35% of your overall calories consumed and prioritize foods high in monounsaturated fats and polyunsaturated fats, like fish, olive oil, nuts and seeds, and avocado. Saturated fats are okay in moderation—especially if you’re getting them from foods you rely on for protein, like meat and eggs—but keep it to under 10% of your overall calories consumed. Keep those basics in mind and fat can be a heavy hitter in your diet, helping to benefit your entire body. That’s something that won’t change, regardless of which diet makes headlines next.

title: Is This a New Golden Age of Dad Rock?
article_text: This story was featured in The Must Read, a newsletter in which our editors recommend one can’t-miss story every weekday.Sign up here to get it in your inbox. In April 2020 I started a new job, working remote from an apartment on the outskirts of brownstone Brooklyn that my family and I had just moved into. I promptly came down with COVID and spent the recommended number of days isolating in a bedroom; my wife had to scoop up my daughter—who would celebrate her first birthday at the end of April, smearing her face with cupcake while our extended family watched over Zoom—whenever she tried to crawl in and say hi. When I eventually took my place at my desk in the living room, most days I would put on the Waxahatchee albumSaint Cloud,released that March, and at some point during its run—“Fire” was a good spot for this—I would go slack, stare into the middle distance, and feel my big feelings. At that timeSaint Cloudseemed sui generis: A newly sober indie rocker’s embrace of country blues with none of the posturing or apparent effort that this description implies. It was—undeniably, to me, a person who resists this word on principle—authentic. (“Its sensory trigger has the power to replace the memory of whatever you call this atrophic season happening around us,” Jeremy Larsonwrotein hisPitchforkreview.) Five years later, though, Waxahatchee’s Katie Crutchfield looks like a herald for a new era of what I will call, in part because so many dads I know are into it, dad rock. And the dads are feasting right now. They have “Elderberry Wine,” theirresistiblerecentBest New Trackby Wednesday, the Asheville, North Carolina, band that once included MJ Lenderman, who collaborated on Waxahatchee’s 2024Saint Cloudfollow-upTigers Bloodand released his own breakthrough album,Manning Fireworks,later that year, and is now on tour, where he is throwing out covers of Bob Dylan and the Counting Crows. Wednesday’s new album is out later this year, and Waxahatchee is opening for Rilo Kiley (whose own tour is the mom-rock reunion of 2025) in October. But the action isn’t limited to the Waxahatchee/MJ Lenderman extended universe.The Nationalfrontman Matt Berninger just released his second solo album,Get Sunk,which ends on a track thatRolling Stone’s Jon Dolandescribes(in the kind of evocative rock-critic language that’s receding as quickly, and tragically, as our hairlines) as “a Nabokov cocktail for literate Gen X bros lurching through the suburban blues one slow-motion epiphany at a time.” The excellent new album by the Philadelphia band Friendship (who will be opening for Wednesdayon their 2025 tour) climaxes with “Resident Evil,” a sinister lament about a shitty roommate; if we’re really in for aSilver Jews Summer, this could be its “Wristwatch.” These are introspective songs that would get you kicked out of karaoke, but they are not necessarily what a colleague of mine calls wife-repeller music. That would be Vermont singer-songwriter Greg Freeman. The first two singles off his forthcoming second album,Burnover,are very good, and I’m also confident that my spouse, who is allergic to Big Thief singer Adrianne Lenker’s “warbling,” isn’t going to tolerate his Neil Young meetsSqueaky-Voiced Teenstyle of singing. The man for whom the term was coined, however, is the powerfully warbly and doleful Cameron Winter, the breakout dad rock star of 2025. While only in his early 20s, Winter earned some dad credibility fronting the noodly Brooklyn group Geese, but he fully cemented his status with his debut solo albumHeavy Metal,which none other than grouchyGQcolumnist Chris Blackcalled“staggeringly good.” Still—not karaoke music. I could widen the dad rock circle to include, say,Sturgill Simpson, who has transfixed dads across the world with an ongoing run of three-hour live sets studded with mind-blowing covers that led Chris Cohento askinGQwhether he’s the greatest live act in music right now, or Vampire Weekend, who are capping their own improvisational sets withcovers requestedby the audience. Covers are obviously great bait for nostalgic dads, and so are extended jams, especially now that so many of us have been conditioned (or reconditioned) by the decade of Dead & Company tours with John Mayer that culminated in this year’s dad-stination Sphere shows. And yes, my dad circle is reading Grayson Haver Currin’s series of definitiveGQprofiles of bands likePhishandKing Gizzard and the Lizard Wizardas well as his piece onLenderman(when they’re not checking Max Read’s newsletter formovie recommendations). But the rising wave of dad rock is one with a strong undercurrent of sadness that Simpson and Vampire Weekend lack. It has roots in country, roots that have branched through bands and songwriters—like Young, Wilco, David Berman, and Bill Callahan—who infuse their ache with noise and tape hiss. If he doesn’t have a wife-repeller voice, today’s dad rocker probably likes a feedback squall. And his wit is almost certainly bleak: Lenderman’s “Every day is a miracle / Not to mention a threat,” meet Friendship’s roommate diss “Something lurking in the dark / Ethan, what happened to your wife?” I say “his,” but another singer that I’d strongly recommend in the slightly acidic Americana vein is Hurray for the Riff Raff, whose terrific February single “Pyramid Scheme” includes the line “Everybody wants to play Billy the Kid / Nobody wants to be Calamity Jane.” I like how Niko Stratis, author ofThe Dad Rock That Made Me a Woman,defines what she calls her taxonomy of the sound: “A dad rock band or album or song or whatever is something that is teaching you something through failure or through some sort of circumstance that has left you with a scar,” she told Sadie Sartini Garner in arecent interviewforGQ.In her 2024Pitchforkprofileby Andy Cush, Katie Crutchfield referenced Jason Molina and Townes Van Zandt, two chroniclers of deep scars: “No one writes about death better than Jason Molina,” she says. “The first few times I heard [‘Hammer Down’], I couldn’t get through it without crying. I’m like, this is so self-aware, this is a person who’s so sick, and he knows he is. And it’s so sad that he struggled like that. And I think Townes, it’s similar. Those guys flew so close to the sun. And maybe that’s why they were able to write this stuff that moves people so much. But I thank God every day that I caught myself before I got to that point.” If Stratis finds lessons in dad rock and Crutchfield sees who she could have become in Molina and Van Zandt, dads like me are just listening to what the kids are up to these days. It is not always pretty. But when your six-year-old is chiming in with Jake Lenderman to singAwooo / Bark at the moon!, it is pretty sweet.

title: Shai Gilgeous-Alexander’s 2025 NBA Playoffs Fits, Definitively Ranked
article_text: Years before Shai Gilgeous-Alexander earned his first MVP, he bagged a far more prestigious award:GQ’s Most Stylish Man of 2022. SGA’s been theNBA’s preeminent fit god for a minute now, regularlytopping lists of the best-dressed athletes in the league. When it comes to dressing for the playoffs—and all the extra eyes and cameras that come with them—he’s long stuck to a tried and true adage the most successful athletes swear by: If you stay ready, you don’t have to get ready. Which is to say, if you’re already the best-dressed dude in the league, when it comes time for the postseason, all you have to do is keep doing your thing. And this year, that’s exactly what he’s done—SGA’s playoff heat has been impeccable on and off the court, with his Oklahoma City Thunder steamrolling their way to the franchise’s first NBA Finals appearance since 2012. With theseries kicking off tonight between OKC and the Indiana Pacers, we’ve crunched the numbers and settled on a definitive ranking of SGA’s 2025 playoff fits. Keep checking back in for further updates as the Finals progress. Listen, even Michael Jordan had an airball or two in his day. Not a bad fit by any means, but a white hoodie andwhite jeansis a safe play from one of the most reliable risk-takers in the NBA. The proportions here are killer, but this knit hoodie/jean combo just doesn’t have the SGA pizzazz we’ve come to expect. Realtree camostarts to get into the bold territory Shai tends to thrive in. A totally solid entry in his run of playoff fits, but not even the best instance of camo on this list. We’re getting to the point on the list where the fits are pretty undeniable and there’s really only nitpicking that separates them. Thevintage vibeon this one is top tier and Shai wears it well, but he’s been sticking with his upcomingConverse Shai 001with most of these fits, and the new-school shoe doesn’t quite mesh with the old-school look. This right here?Thisis how you wear camo. Shai’s sleeveless fits are always among the best in his arsenal, and this one comes with the added bonus of a dope pair of slouchydouble-knee pants. Basically every piece of this is interesting on its own—the pattern of the sweater, the big zipper, the stitching on the jeans, the cool, drapey coat. Elite work from an elite player. Speaking of elite pattern mixing: snakeskin over the cable-knit. His mind! Canada’s finest knows how to wear the hell out of aCanadian tuxedo(or two—more on that later). This is the sort of effortless swag that almost every player in the league is aspiring to when they get dressed for a tunnel walk. For Shai, it’s just business as usual. If I (33, bad knee, mostly good for threes and hustle) were about to go out and ruin the hopes and dreams of an NBA franchise, this is what I would wear to do it. Is it kind of yassfiiedThe Matrix-core? Yeah. Does it still work? Somehow, yes. That’s the magic of Shai. For a guy best known for audacious and off-kilter designer pieces, Shai has a deeply enviableworkwear lineup. Maybe it’d get a little stale if he wore such classic gear before every game, but it’s a major stunt when incorporated into his otherwise out-there playoff attire. Bro. Bro, please. Bro, my girl is watching this game, please, bro. Art. Pure art. A crispselvedge indigoCanadian tux, Realtree camo gloves, the Shai 001 in Timbs-adjacent buckwheat. His finest hour in a postseason of incredible tunnel fits.

title: Noah and Timex Dropped Another Instant-Classic $200 Watch
article_text: All products featured on GQ are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links. Noah has long been a reliable source of '90s skater vibes and old-money style. But recently it’s also become known as one-half of the duo behindone of the most coveted watches $200 can buy. If, that is, you managed to cop it in time. The watch in question was last June’s Noah x Timex Sun and Moon Watch, a gold-tonedTank-style tickerwith a sun and moon display and a black faux-croc strap that sold out in a matter of minutes, earning it the title of theHottest Affordable Watch of the Year(and a subsequentreboot.) Fortunately for the many folks who missed out on that drop, the new Noah x Timex Lighthouse Watch offers a similarly enticing proposition. With its croco pattern leather strap, slim gold-tone case, and a dial printed with a charcoal drawing of a lighthouse, the Noah x Timex Lighthouse Watch sits alongside the brand’sgraphic teesandseersucker suitsin the Venn diagram of repentant-skate-rat prep. Timex x Noah Noah Like the brand’s previous Timex collab, it also riffs on one of the most iconic watch silhouettes of the 20th century. As the Noah x Timex Sun and Moon Watch did with the Cartier Tank, the Noah x Timex Lighthouse Watch pays subtle homage to thePatek Philippe Golden Ellipse, whose rounded case and barely-there hands have been a part of the Swiss watchmaker’s catalog since the 1960s. For Noah designer Brendon Babenzien, who founded the label with his wife, Estelle Bailey-Babenzien and now alsooversees J.Crew's menswear, the new watch is less about paying homage to an icon of luxury watchmaking and more about evoking the feel of his hometown on Long Island. “​I grew up not far from the Fire Island Lighthouse, and it was always in the backdrop of my life, so I want[ed] a lighthouse on the watch,” he explains. It’s also the first Noah watch Babenzien plans to cop for himself. “I'm not a big-time watch guy. I'm not, like,anti-watch, but I just never really got into watches the way others have,” he says. “But this is the one I'm going to wear.” Other fans ofbudget-friendly watcheswith impeccable menswear credentials should consider doing the same. The Noah x Timex Lighthouse watch isavailable for pre-orderfrom June 5th through June 12th. For more timely ticker recommendations, check out theGQ Watch Shop.

title: NBA Finals Preview: Pacers-Thunder May Not Be a Long Series, But It Will be Entertaining
article_text: Trying to score on theOklahoma City Thunder’s defensecan be like trying to ram a feather through a brick wall. Trying to contain theIndiana Pacers’ offenseis similar to catching a gust of wind with an old sock. Both can border on impossible, and you need the right personnel to achieve either dream, which is what will make the 2025 NBA Finals such an alluring watch. Please, for the love of basketball, spare us all your thoughts about the geographic locations of each team somehow being a detriment. While it is true that a coterie of expensive suits in Midtown Manhattan wanted, for rating purposes, something a little glitzier than Oklahoma City-Indianapolis—the 20th and 16thmost-populous cities in the US—you, dear reader, are not theNational Basketball Association. You are a person. And if you’re a fan of pedal-to-the-metal hoops, you should be excited about this series. In boxing, they say that styles make fights. If these upcoming games were taking place in the ring, the canvas would resemble a Jackson Pollock painting. Among teams who have played at least 10 games this postseason, the Thunder and Pacers are the two whoplay at the fastest pace. These teams—and, blessedly, their young legs—love to run, which makes for some of the most entertaining basketball there is. The antidote to the attention span crisis is an OKC-Indy matchup, because they won’t leave any time to take your eyes off the screen. If thereisany time during the Finals to quickly check your phone or, I don’t know, engage with your loved ones, it’ll be whenShai Gilgeous-Alexanderis at the free throw line. Because believe me, he will be a frequent attendee. SGA—the principal player in the series, and maybe, at least in the vacuum of this particular season, the entire league—has averaged 9.2 foul shots per game during the Thunder’s playoff run. The measured take is that in order to be the type of heavyweight he wants to be, Gilgeous-Alexanderhasto draw these whistles. His style of play utilizes an endless supply of yo-yoing drives to the rim, the type that gets a player scratched and clawed with so much regularity that you could argue a foul happens more often than not. It’s just on the referee to call them. The extremist, most-irritating-guy-at-the-bar take is that Shai is an indefensible foul baiter and free throw merchant who should be ashamed of his every dribble. These are all things loudly crowed by people who are willingly missing the forest for the trees. Getting to the line is a necessary part ofany MVP’s game, and just because he gets a handful of ticky tack fouls every quarter doesn’t mean that Gilgeous-Alexander is a grifter who’s in bed with the officials. It means he understands his role—which, at the moment, is to be the brightest player on the NBA’s brightest stage. On a wider level, the free throw conversation is the odds-on favorite to be the dominant topic of these Finals. It’s nice to have a monocultural sports thing! “Does Shai need to kick his flopping addiction?” is something you can discuss with a rando at the grocery store, your grandparents, or your friend’s kid in equal aptitude. That’s what these tentpole sporting events are all about, after all: grasping onto that increasingly fleeting feeling that we’re all watching the same thing and analyzing it in similar ways. Speaking of which, get ready to hear all about the Pacers’ three-point shooting, especially if they go cold in Oklahoma and drop the first two games,orcatch a hot streak and steal one of them. Indiana owns the best three-point percentage and offensive rating of any team that logged at least 10 playoff games, and every member of their starting lineup is more than qualified from deep. Sweet shooting—particularly the way the Pacers do it, which is often the product of swinging ball movement that gets someone wide open—is one of the more pleasurable things to watch on a basketball court. Don’t expect Aaron Nesmith to connect on 53% of his threes like he did in theEastern Conference Finals against the Knicks. But that barrage, plus Conference Final MVP Pascal Siakam knocking in half of his attempts, and mustachioed role player Ben Sheppard draining 55%,does prove that Indiana is capable of snapping the nets. Lightning can strike twice, and when it does, it’s a powerful way to counteract the Thunder. (By the way, Tyrese Haliburton shot uncharacteristically poorly against New York. Some positive regression to the mean is almost surely coming his way.) So, we’ve got green, energetic, fresh faces going at it for a championship—prepare yourself for the first firmlyGen ZFinals MVP, by the way—but we’ve also got some guys who’ve been around the block. The oldest player on the Thunder, a team so complete that they can’t possibly be this young, is 31-year-old icon Alex Caruso. He is, without question, one of the more annoying players in the NBA. What I mean by that is that playing against Alex Caruso looks about as enjoyable as wrestling in a pit of quicksand. With his pestilent defense and non-stop freneticism, Caruso shadows opposing ballhandlers better than almost anyone. While the task of guarding Haliburton will mostly fall to fellow defensive stopper Luguentz Dort, there will undoubtedly be some instances where Caruso is summoned off the bench with the sole directive of pissing Haliburton off. Like Caruso, the Pacers have a player in their second unit who I imagine would be flattered by the “annoying” label. T.J. McConnell—the lazy fan would call him a gym rat, a scrappy veteran, or ashameless instigator; the educated ball knower would call himEdie Falco’s biggest opp—is playing in his first NBA Finals after 10 full years of trying. Undrafted like Caruso, and about four inches shorter, McConnell has never met a challenge he didn’t relish. Remember in the 2015 Finals, when little guy legendMatthew Dellavedova had to be hospitalized for severe cramping, needing an IV after chasing Steph Curry around? If McConnell senses a chance to disrupt Gilgeous-Alexander all the way to a monumental upset, don’t be surprised if the Pacers install a drip bag for him right there on the bench. We could go on and on about the secondary and tertiary elements that will make this series compelling for both casuals and basketball nerds alike. The fact that the league will crown its seventh different champion in the last seven years is very cool in its own right, as is the chance for both franchises to earn their first ring. (I don’t care what the NBA’s official stance on this is, the Seattle SuperSonics’ 1979 championship doesnotcount for Oklahoma City.) A win for the Thunder will validate their player development prowess. Jalen Williams—a first-time All-Star and extremely ripe second banana to Gilgeous-Alexander—is all of 24 years old.Avid reader Chet Holmgrenis 23. Rotation players Jaylin Williams and Cason Wallace are 22 and 21, respectively. Oklahoma City is the only organization all four of them have ever known, and bringing home a title this soon would leave no doubt as to which team is getting the most out of its puppies. In the other corner, watchingMyles Turnerraise a banner after a decade of steady, quietly productive grinding in Indiana would be truly touching. The Pacers can’t claim the same style of draft-picks-to-diamonds construction that got Oklahoma City to the top, but their front office’s extremely shrewd trades for Haliburton, Siakam, and Nesmith also deserve a whole acre of flowers. The head coaches’ 25-year age gap (Indiana’s Rick Carlisle, boomer, bald; Oklahoma City’s Mark Daigneault, millennial, coiffed) makes for a fun aesthetic wrinkle as well. And we haven’t even talked about the omnipresent “Yes ‘Cers” shirts! Should you feel inclined to bet on this series—and, I say this grimly, statistically speaking I know a lot of you will—I’d advise you to pick OKC ten out of ten times. They were the best team in the regular season, have remained the best team in the playoffs, and have the luxury of the best player in the Finals being on their roster. It’s likely that they’ll make quick work of the Pacers, but that shouldn’t damage the entertainment value of each individual contest. Either way, when all is said and done, a city in what many would consider a flyover state will be hosting its first NBAchampionship parade. You can complain about that city not being in a large enough media market to truly stimulate the sports economy (like a mark), or you can sit back and watch a bunch of high-level games that will conceivably end in the 120s, ushering in a new tide of basketball supremacy. Call it whatever you want—just don’t call it boring.

title: Was King Charles Reluctant to Give Prince Archie and Princess Lilibet Passports With Their Royal Titles?
article_text: This year,Meghan Marklehas emphasized that “Sussex” is the surname she shares withPrince Harryand their two children,Prince ArchieandPrincess Lilibet of Sussex.But a recent report fromThe Guardianrevealed that a recent passport snafu led the duke and duchess to consider giving their children different legal names. According to the newspaper, Harry and Meghan applied for British passports for their children, which were so delayed that the couple’s lawyers sent a letter expressing a desire to request access to the information under the terms of General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a data protection law. Days after the letter was sent,The Guardianreports, the UK government issued passports for Archie and Lili. "There was clear reluctance to issue passports for the kids,” a source close to Meghan and Harry told the newspaper. "The king hadn’t wanted Archie and Lili to carry the titles, most of all the HRH, and the British passports, once created, would be the first and perhaps the only legal proof of their names.” A spokesperson for the couple toldVanity Fair,“We do not comment on private issues pertaining to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex’s children.” The behind-the-scenes discussions about the Sussex children and the complicated subject of their legal names has been in the news recently after theMail on Sunday’sRichard Edenreportedthat the couple once considered changing their legal names to “Spencer,” the maiden name of Princess Diana.VFunderstands that Prince Harry once spoke to his maternal uncleCharles Spencerabout the family name but did not pursue a legal name change. “He’s now closer to his mother’s family than his immediate family,” a source close to the family toldVF. “At one point Harry mooted the idea of taking the Spencer name, but rejected it because he knew it would be way too controversial and yet another legal headache.” Spencer has been a source of support for Harry during the last few years. “Harry is very close to his maternal side of the family, and in all of this his uncle Earl Spencer has been a shoulder to cry on,” the source added. “Harry has stayed with his uncle when he’s been over in the UK and is always invited to join the Spencers for Christmas.” An Exclusive First Look atWicked: For Good The Dizzying Rise of MAHA WarriorCalley Means, RFK Jr.’s Right-Hand Man The UnsinkableKathy Bates From RFK Jr. to Patrick Schwarzenegger, a Brief Guide tothe Kennedy Family All theCast MembersThat Might LeaveSNLThis Fall Rick Steveson Rejecting Fascism at Home and Fears of Trump Abroad Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Nation Watches With Glee as Musk and Trump Turn on Each Other
article_text: Donald TrumpandElon Muskhave gone from happily using each other for mutual benefit to openly slagging each other off in public. Yes, it is a complete and total shock that the relationship between these two extremely well-adjusted, deeply altruistic, entirely compos mentis individuals has broken down, possibly for good. On Thursday, Musk took to social media to go scorched-earth on the president in a series of escalating posts that caused shares ofTesla to plungeand, as of this writing, included this claim: This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. Musk preceded that accusation by calling Trump a literal ingrate,writing, “Without me, Trump would have lost the election, Dems would control the House and the Republicans would be 51-49 in the Senate. Such ingratitude.” Those comments were undoubtedly inspired by Oval Officeremarksin which the president shared that he was “very disappointed in Elon,” whom he said he “helped…a lot.” That disappointment stemmed from Musk’s public declaration on Tuesday that Trump’s spending bill was a “disgusting abomination.” How did it come to this? After all, it wasn’t so long ago that these two werebasically roommatesand/orfather and son. Theyheld rallies together. They performedinfomercialsin front of the White House. MuskboughtTrump a second term, while Trumpthreatened jail sentences for peopledoing harm to Teslas. Sure, Trump was using Musk for his money and Musk was using Trump for power, but still! Anyway, it appears it’s now Trump’s turn to lob one across the net, and there’s no telling in which direction he’ll go. Will he slap Musk with one of hispatented mean nicknames? Will he claim he didn’t need Musk’s money to win the election? Will he weigh in on Musk’sclaimthat he is “NOT taking drugs”? Hey, maybe he’ll deport the guy! (Steve Bannonhassaidhe should.) Sure, the South African–born billionaire is a dual US-Canadian citizen, but that doesn’tmatter anymore! title: Who Will Win at the 2025 Tony Awards?
article_text: The 78th Tony Awards ceremony will take place on Sunday, June 8, honoring the best and brightest of the 2024-2025 Broadway season. It’s been a wild and woolly year on the Great White Way, dominated bymovie-star-laden, but otherwise lackluster, productionsof classics old and new (Othello,Glengarry Glen Ross), as well as buzzy musical transfers (Sunset Blvd.) and revivals (Gypsy). Money has been made, stars have been born, and a few scrappy upstarts (Oh, Mary!,Maybe Happy Ending) have managed to break through the noise. So, who will receive a shiny trophy for their theatrical troubles on Sunday? On this week’sLittle Gold Menpodcast, cohostRichard Lawsonassembles a panel of Broadway experts—Vanity Fair’sChris Murphy,Vulturetheater criticJackson McHenry,and entertainment writerEsther Zuckerman—to break down the major categories and make some semi-confident predictions. Perhaps the biggest title bout of the evening will be found—as it often is—in the lead actress in a musical category, wheresix-time Tony winnerAudra McDonaldwill stare down former Pussycat Doll turnedlauded stage performerNicole Scherzinger. McDonald’s long awaited turn inGypsyhas been ballyhooed by some, pooh-poohed by others. Scherzinger has received near unanimous praise for her cracked, decidedly modern version of Norma Desmond inSunset Blvd., but her campaign could be marred by some offstage controversy involving a red hat. We’re giving the narrowest of edges to Scherzinger, but one should never count out Audra McDonald. If she wins, she will break her own record as the most Tony-awarded actor of all time. Our panelists were all in agreement that the brilliantCole Escolashouldwin best lead actor in a play for their delightfully gonzo turn as a delightfully gonzo Mary Todd Lincoln inOh, Mary!But it’s possible that Escola—a Brooklyn alt-comedy legend finally enjoying mainstream success—could lose out to a big name likeGeorge Clooney,whoseGood Night, and Good Luckwas respectfully received when it opened this spring. (The same cannot be said forClooney’s dye job.) The Tonys have long found it difficult to resist giving big celebrities awards—though that tide has turned some of late, a fact perhaps best evidenced this year by the absence ofOthellostarDenzel Washingtonon the nominees list. Another young upstart is challenging some high-profile names in the lead actor in a musical category.Tom Francis,the 20-something British hunk who commandingly leadsSunset Blvd., is squaring off against Emmy winnerDarren Criss(who plays a lovelorn robot inMaybe Happy Ending) and Broadway royaltyJonathan Groff(who plays Bobby Darin inJust In Time). We suspect one of the flashier names will prevail over Francis—Groff could quite possibly repeat his win from last year—though we think Escola will beat Mr. Clooney.Oh, Mary!is one of the sensations of the season, embodying the kind of downtown-to-Midtown Cinderella narrative the Tony voters love. You can hear the case for those predictions and more on this week’s episode, along with some commentary on the merit (or lack thereof) of theStranger Thingsplay, a debate about new musicalDead Outlaw, and some passion picks for who should win in the featured actor categories. Happy Tonys season to those who celebrate! Which is to say, happy Pride. title: Karine Jean-Pierre, Joe Biden’s Ex–Press Secretary, Urges Democrats to Ditch the Democratic Party
article_text: Karine Jean-Pierre,Joe Biden’s former press secretary, has used her forthcoming memoir to urge Democrats to ditch the party and become independents, a move she personally made sometime after leaving the White House. And a number of ex-administration staffers are not taking it well! In the wake of thenewssurrounding Jean-Pierre’s defection, and her claims about the Democratic Party inIndependent: A Look Inside a Broken White House, Outside the Party Lines,more than two dozen former Biden administration officials took to Axios togripeabout the ex–press secretary. One former White House official raged that Jean-Pierre is positioning herself “as an outsider when [she] not only...enjoyed the perks of extreme proximity to power” and “the name recognition needed to sell books off your name,” saying, “It’s difficult to see how this is anything but a bizarre cash grab.” Another told the outlet that Jean-Pierre was “one of the most ineffectual and unprepared people I’ve ever worked with,” claiming, “She didn’t know how to manage a team, didn’t know how to shape or deliver a message, and often created more problems than she solved.” Yet another claimed, “The amount of time that was spent coddling [Jean-Pierre] and appeasing her was astronomical compared to our attention on actual matters of substance.” Jean-Pierre did not respond to Axios’s requests for comment. Jean-Pierre did not immediately respond toVanity Fair’s request for comment. Last February at the Harvard Kennedy School Institute of Politics, Jean-Pierresaidthat the “toughest thing“ to witness in the three weeks between Biden’s disastrous debate performance and his announcement that he was dropping out of the race was the Democratic “firing squad.” “I had never seen a party do that in the way that they did, and it was hurtful and sad to see that happening—a firing squad around a person who I believed was a true patriot,” she said. In a press release announcing her book, which will be published in October, Jean-Pierrewrote: “Until January 20, I was responsible for speaking on behalf of the President of the United States. At noon on that day, I became a private citizen who, like all Americans and many of our allies around the world, had to contend with what was to come next for our country. I determined that the danger we face as a country requires freeing ourselves of boxes. We need to be willing to exercise the ability to think creatively and plan strategically. We need to be clear-eyed and questioning, rather than blindly loyal and obedient as we may have been in the past.” Jean-Pierre does not appear to have commented on the criticism from her former colleagues, but it’s safe to say she may not be appearing at Biden staffer reunions any time soon. title: Stephen Miller Is Escalating His Immigration Crackdown With a New Travel Ban
article_text: Donald Trump’s mass deportation effort has beenlagging behind his goal. His vice president,JD Vance, at one pointforecast a million deportations a year this term; the administration hasn’t only been well behind that lofty number—they’ve struggled to keep pace with removals last year, whenJoe Bidenwas still president, and have called on migrants to “self-deport” to help boost their stats. That’s been a point of frustration forStephen Miller, the administration’s resident anti-immigration zealot. Unsatisfied with the pace of deportations thus far, he has demanded recently that Immigrations and Customs Enforcement make no fewer than 3,000 arrests a day—and threatened to fire officials who hold them back from meeting that quota. They haven’t quite hit that, but ICE this week recorded itsmost detentions in a single day, according to NBC News, arresting more than 2,200 people Tuesday—the result, it seems, of more aggressive tactics by authorities. Indeed, in recent days, there have beenreportsacross the country of migrants enrolled in alternative to detention programs being arrested after appearing at ICE offices for check-ins. In one instance, on Wednesday,at least 10 were arrestedin downtown Chicago, apparently after receiving text messages instructing them to check in with ICE; in a chaotic scene, masked agents loaded detainees into vans as community members, and elected officials, protested. “They’re kidnapping people,” Chicago aldermanByron Sigcho-LopeztoldWGN News. The Trump administration has insisted, throughout its shock and awe immigration program this year, that it is targeting criminals—the “worst of the worst,” as Homeland Security SecretaryKristi Noemputs it. But it is obviously going much farther than that, as the arrests at ICE check-ins underscore: These were people apparently following the directions—showing up to appearances, as they were told—and they were arrested for it. “The Trump Administration does not care if you are complying with the law because they do not respect the rule of law,” Illinois RepresentativeDelia Ramirez, who called for Noem’s resignation,wroteWednesday. “They do not care if you have constitutional rights because they do not respect the Constitution.” “They only care about the arbitrary deportation quotas set by [Stephen] Miller,” Ramirez added. In seeking to meet those quotas, the administration may be making Americans less safe: It hasdiverted resources and personnelaway from federal law enforcement toward arresting undocumented immigrants, and effectively discouraged migrants from appearing in court or at check-ins out of fear of being arrested. The escalation comes after Trump officials directed immigration authorities to “turn the creative knob up to 11” and “push the envelope,” as the Guardianreported: “If it involves handcuffs on wrists,” one official said, “it’s probably worth pursuing.” It also came as Trumpissued a new travel banWednesday evening, restricting nationals from 12 countries—Afghanistan, Burma, Chad, Republic of the Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Haiti, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, and Yemen—from entering the United States. “We don’t want them,” Trumpsaidin a video announcing the ban. Trump cited the attack on Jewish demonstrators in Boulder, Colorado, as he announced the executive order. But the alleged attacker—Mohamed Sabry Soliman—is a national of Egypt, which was not included in the new ban. title: Tom Hanks, Bursting with Pride, Supports His Daughter’s Raw, Revealing Memoir
article_text: More than one person, surely, has looked atTom Hanksand thought, “Oh yeah, Father’s Day is just around the corner, I better make sure to send a card.” His recent remarks about his actual daughterE.A. Hanks’recent memoir,The 10: A Memoir of Family and the Open Road, are peak sweet dad stuff, even while discussing the book’s sometimes difficult subject matter. In the book, E.A., now 43, describes physical and emotional abuse from her mother, Samantha Lewes, after she and Tom divorced in 1987 shortly before she turned 5. After the split, Lewes got primary custody of E.A. and older brotherColin Hanksin Sacramento. In the book, E.A. describes her life from the ages of 5 to 14, when in the aftermath of emotional abuse turning physical and she moved to Los Angeles to live with her father, as “years filled with confusion, violence, deprivation, and love,” with a mother who had undiagnosed mental health issues and an ongoing struggle with addiction. Lewes died of cancer in 2002. Tom was an early reader of his daughter’s memoir, hetoldAccess Hollywoodlate last month on the red carpet of hislatest film,The Phoenician Scheme, and was bursting with fatherly pride for his only daughter. (He has two more sons,TrumanandChet, withRita Wilson, half-brothers to E.A. and Colin.) “It’s a pride because she shares it with me, she’s very open about what the process is,” he said of his daughter’s writing, which she toldVanity Fairwas inspired partly by reading her mother’s old diaries that she found in storage. “She’s a knockout, always has been,” Tom said. “As a dad—if you’ve had kids, you realize that you see who they are when they’re about 6 weeks old. Their personality is there. Their temper, the way they see the world is demonstrated in their body language and on their face.” And what he saw then holds true now, he said: “I’m not surprised that my daughter had the wherewithal as well as the curiosity as well as the—I’m gonna say perhaps the kind ofshoot herself in the footwherewithal—to examine this thing that I think she was incredibly honest about. One is that we all come from checkered, cracked lives, all of us.” Both E.A. and her father point out that despite having what Tom calls a “copyrighted last name,” she knew struggle spending her childhood in her mother’s home, and what it felt like to be both inside and outside of the glow of the spotlight on her father as his public profile rose. E.A., aVanity FairandNew York Timescontributor,toldVFin a recent interviewthat “I wasn’t born on third base, but we moved there in the ’90s. No matter how difficult my childhood with my mother was, the material reality is that I don’t have student loans. That’s how the privilege really does its magic: it sets you up with the right schools, the right jobs, the safety net. It opens all the doors, but the nuance is that it doesn’t keep them open.” She described her father’s fame as somewhat “catastrophic” in its effect on her mother, who also acted but never found widespread recognition. “She felt that his stature in the world obliterated her and any chance she had at continuing her stage career,” she toldVF. “The uncomfortable truth, and there’s a lot of them in this book, is she didn’t really have a career, and her ex-husband becomingthe Tom Hankswas more insult to injury than significant impediment.” Tom, who celebrated the book's April release with a ticketed publication day conversation with her at 92Y in New York City, praised his daughter for her embrace of these difficult nuances and examinations of privilege and jealousy, among other thorny issues that come with examining one’s family and childhood. “She leans into everything of it, and I think that anybody who does that is a bold, journalistic, literate mind,” he said, “and I’m just thrilled that I can say this about my daughter.” The admiration is mutual. As E.A. toldVF, “From the outset, he has supportedThe 10. Whether it was swapping cars with me, helping me pick out camping gear, or being the first reader. The conversation we had once he had read a very early draft was exactly what I needed to hear, which was that I had depicted my mother accurately. This is what it was like to both love and fear her.” An Exclusive First Look atWicked: For Good The Dizzying Rise of MAHA WarriorCalley Means, RFK Jr.’s Right-Hand Man The UnsinkableKathy Bates From RFK Jr. to Patrick Schwarzenegger, a Brief Guide tothe Kennedy Family All theCast MembersThat Might LeaveSNLThis Fall Rick Steveson Rejecting Fascism at Home and Fears of Trump Abroad Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years.
