title: The Black Republican Mafia Is the DC Group Chat Everyone Wants to Join
article_text: On a rainy morning in May, 26-year-oldEmery Washington,a deputy press secretary in the US Department of Energy, turns onSoulja Boyand skims through the messages in her group chat, the Black Republican Mafia, the text thread of cool kids in the Trump administration—all in their 20s with a visible presence in the conservative scene. On any day, conversation can veer fromJasmine CrocketttoChris Brown’s mug shot, to the latest gossip on the Hill. And, unlike the older run Republican Party group chats, there is absolutely no way anyone’s getting added by accident. Washington puts on cowboy boots and feeds her dogs, Frankie and Biggie. With a mocha in hand, she gets in her car and drives to downtown DC, her phone buzzing incessantly with chatter; eventually she’ll have to mute it because it simply gets to be “too much.” “We are the official MAGA ambassadors to the Black community here in DC,”CJ Pearson,a 22-year-old youth advisor for the RNC who also belongs to the group, tells me. The other members areChristian Newton,the 23-year-old chief of staff at the Department of Energy’s Office of Science,Erik Conyers,a 25-year-old Trump fundraiser and event planner, andJaniyah Thomas,who ran Black media for the president during his 2024 campaign. “They represent the future of Trump’s transformational ‘America First’ legacy within the Republican Party and are the MAGA standard-bearers of what was originally considered a one-time, extremist political movement but is now the proud and loud political majority of this country,”Lynne Patton,the director of minority outreach at the White House tells me. The friends met on the campaign trail and bonded over what they felt was a lack of Black staffers. Thomas says the group bonded partly because of how ostracized they felt by their friends and families for being young, Black, and conservative. Conyers grew up in a Democratic household in Virginia and went through the Senate Page Program whenBarack Obamawas in the White House—the only Black page in his cohort. “Everyone wanted me to be a Democrat,” Conyers said. “My family wanted that, but I knew that there were things that I didn’t agree with.” Conyers maintains relationships with family and friends from back home, but not without some pushback. “They think I’m crazy, but they still support me,” he told me over the phone. “We know what parameters we should and shouldn’t discuss.” Now that it may be seen as trendy to be a conservative in America, they no longer feel self-conscious about their political beliefs. But the group didn’t get its name until February, when someone approached them at a party and said, “You know what we call you guys behind your back? The Black Republican Mafia,” Conyers tells me. They decided it was the perfect moniker. The mafia have become an emblem of a new era of young conservatism: one that is brash, ambitious, and loves to party. The group is part of a trend in the 2024 election, whenAmericansbetween 18 and 29shifted favorablytoward the Republican Party—although, according to analysis by Tufts University’s Center for Information and Research on Civic Learning and Engagement(CIRCLE),their attitudes and interests diverged from older conservatives on issues like climate change, abortion, and immigration. At the same time, support for Democratsdecreasedamong young Black voters. In 2024, they voted forKamala Harrisby a 50-point margin,down from 2020, when Black youth supportedJoe Bidenby a 77-point margin, according to surveying by the Associated Press. CIRCLE researchers observed that “among the Black electorate, young voters gave President Trump the highest support compared to other age groups, continuing a 2020 shift in which Black voters under the age of 45 started switching their preference.” When I asked why Trump’s second term has been particularly welcoming to this group, they say that the president is willing to engage with and listen to the younger people he employs, that he is transparent about what he is doing in government and shares everything on social media, and that they don’t have to shrink themselves or change to fit in with his administration. “The fact that there are young conservatives like us that are so involved and spearheading a lot of the efforts to support President Trump, and support his agenda, really, I think is super special,” Newton says. “We have hired more political appointees and at a quicker rate than any administration ever has…. It shows that the president is committed to making sure we get stuff going.” Pearson first met Trump at Mar-a-Lago in 2022; he recalled him being “passionately enthusiastic” about young people playing a bigger role in the party. He has a photograph with the president pinned on his Instagram page. Despite Trump’s campaignagainst DEIpolicies orrollback of civil rights protections,some members of the group say they don’t see his comments or actions as racist. “The president eliminating DEI is not racist, because none of my friends needed DEI to get to where they are,” Pearson says. “From what I’ve seen from the president, every interaction that I’ve had with him, and also going back to his record, this is a president who has, time and again, delivered for the Black community.” When the group goes out, it’s usually to DC’s latest members club, The Ned, Joe’s Seafood, Prime Steak and Stone Crab next to the White House, or The Park at 14th for Sunday lunch. Erik Conyers loves gossip and a French 75, and can recite the rest of the group's go-to drink orders by heart. For CJ, it’s a whisky sour, Emery, a vodka soda, Janiya loves a prosecco, and Christian, a vodka soda with lime. Once, when someone approached Conyers and asked if they could potentially join the group, his response was, “There’s really nothing you can do.” Another person has reportedly asked five times. For now, the group chat shows no sign of growing, but if they were to admit a new member, they say it would beXaviaer DuRousseau,a 28-year-old conservative social media star based in Los Angeles. DuRousseau is a “friend of the group,” says Pearson, but he would have to live in DC for the invite to be formally extended. title: Trump Thinks Autopen Is Only Bad When Biden Does It
article_text: In the latest turn in the ongoing revenge fantasy that isDonald Trump’ssecond administration, on Wednesday the presidentissued a memorandum, instructing the Department of Justice to investigatePresident Biden’s use of the autopen. The tool is basically a tiny printer programmed to reproduce a signature via a robotic arm holding a pen. It’s used widely in government anddates backto the days ofThomas Jefferson.Even Trump has repeatedly used it himself. But the memo instructs the White House counsel, as well as the attorney general, to investigate “whether certain individuals conspired to deceive the public about Biden’s mental state and unconstitutionally exercise the authorities and responsibilities of the President.” It specifically orders them to investigate which documents—from executive orders to clemency grants—were signed with an autopen under Biden. These investigations would, presumably, serve as precursors to trying to invalidate those policies and pardons. Andthatwould be a precursor to lifting, among other things, the pardons Biden granted to his family and members of the House Select Committee that investigated the January 6th attack. At least, that’s how Trump sees it. “The ‘Pardons’ that Sleepy Joe Biden gave to the Unselect Committee of Political Thugs, and many others, are hereby declared VOID, VACANT, AND OF NO FURTHER FORCE OR EFFECT, because of the fact that they were done by Autopen,”he wroteon Truth Social in March. The problem is most legal scholars (that is, most scholars who don’t work for the Heritage Foundation wherethese ideas first started kicking around) say that not only is there no way to undo a pardon, but there’s no requirement that pardons even be signed. “The argument that the pardon fails because it was signed by an autopen fails at the get-go,”Jay Wexler, a professor of constitutional law at Boston University School of Law,recently toldNPR. In fact, during theGeorge W. Bushadministration, the Department of Justice alsolaid out a truly tediously detailed legal argumentfor why the autopen is an acceptable form of presidential signature. Ina statement to news outletsWednesday, Biden said, “Let me be clear: I made the decisions during my presidency. I made the decisions about the pardons, executive orders, legislation, and proclamations. Any suggestion that I didn’t is ridiculous and false.” To Trump the one true power is the power of the presidential pen. The only way he can see to invalidate what Biden did with that power is to claim it wasn’t actually him wielding it at all. Even if the legal argument fails, simply harassing his political enemies is half the battle. title: Zoe Saldaña on How Winning an Oscar Rekindled Her Spark, Her Relationship to Jewelry and Parenting
article_text: Late last month, Oscar winnerZoe Saldañawas a guest of honor, alongsideAlexander Skarsgård,Deepika Padukone, andAnna Sawai, as Cartier presented its new high jewelry collection, En Équilibre, at the Artipelag cultural center in Stockholm. The new collection includes necklaces, earrings, and rings whose precious charm references the balance between symmetries and asymmetries, the harmony between empty and full spaces, and the play of colors inspired, as always for the maison, by the imperfect perfection of nature. As true balance requires, the search for essentiality, precision, and a certain rigor is certainly not at the expense of inspiration, imagination and wonder. In short, this is a collection in which the dear old principle of opposites attracting each other takes on a new and full meaning. Opposites such as gentleness and stubbornness, strength and being delicate, determination and sensitivity, which are characteristic of Saldaña in her acting career. Vanity Fair spoke with Saldaña about her Oscar win, her relationship to jewelry and her greatest gift. Photo courtesy Cartier. Vanity Fair: How would you define your relationship to jewelry? Zoe Saldaña:I feel that my relationship with jewelry is intensifying as I grow up, because I can appreciate it in a deeper and deeper way: it's a kind of rediscovery of how precious it is to own a timeless piece that you can share with your family and pass down from generation to generation. Thanks to Cartier, I am having a unique experience in the world of jewelry, from buying the stones to the design to the craftsmanship by which they are made. It is simply wonderful. Photo courtesy Cartier. Do you feel attuned with this particular collection, En Équilibre? I feel an affinity with all Cartier pieces, because I love the harmony of inspiration that this fashion house has always drawn from nature, flora and fauna, which it has redesigned and reinvented to create these pieces that are simply beautiful. So even if I'm wearing something that I know was made by a man or a woman, I feel like it's a natural element. It's a strange emotion to describe. What is your greatest gift, or quality, as an actress and as a human being? I'm a very dedicated person. I take great pride in always giving 150 percent of myself, because when I give less, I feel very disappointed. I can be very, very hard on myself. I'm also learning to appreciate more what I do, and that's a process just by accepting that I'm human. I give it my all, in short, and I try to be grateful for the experience I am having. As a person, however, I am very loyal. Do you think thatwinning an Oscarwill have an impact on your career and your choices for the future, one way or another? You know, usually awards like this affect an actor's career for the better. At my age, after all the years I've spent doing this work, if there's one big lesson I've learned from this award is that it has been able to rekindle that spark in me that for some reason I thought I didn't need to have anymore. And that spark allows me, as a woman, to continue to strive to grow and age gracefully. I think it is as if a ticking clock looms over us women, marking time that passes quickly, a clock that has been imposed on us by others. Reminding myself that this is a job I can do until the end of my days is really rewarding. Anna Sawai. Photo courtesy Cartier. Alexander Skarsgård. Photo courtesy Cartier. In your speech at the Oscars you thanked your family, both your parents and the one you have built with your husband Marco, who is Italian. How has your family influenced you? It's about life, simply: the one that my family of origin gave me, and the one that I have now formed with my husband, it's a life that we continue to build together. It is the greatest gift: the fact that I can live a full life every day, full of people of whom I always, every moment, strive to be worthy. What is your favorite city in Italy? I really like Lake Garda, because that is where my husband is from. But I've also come to really appreciate Liguria, the whole region: the Italian Riviera for me is the place where the climate is just perfect, it's never too cold or too hot. The water is delicious. And the food: incredible. Photo courtesy Cartier. As a mother of three boys, what values or lessons are you passing on to them about women? I think the most important lesson we are passing on to our children is to continue to be curious about women. Right now our oldest children, the twins, are 10 years old, and our youngest is 8: I want them to understand very early on that there hasn't always been equality for women because, as you know, equality is something that women have fought for and must continue to fight for. I want my children if they see something wrong, an injustice, to say so. They are learning almost automatically to always support women and make them feel supported. The little one found out this year that in sports girls are treated differently than boys, they don't get paid as much as them even though they do everything the boys do, and he couldn't get over it. When my sons come out of their family environment, Italian and Latin, in which women are in charge of everything, and they see that in the world things are not the same, that sometimes women are not treated the same as men, they are not supported in the same way, they get very discouraged. I really appreciate the fact that they are curious about this, that they want to understand why these situations happen. All we can do as parents is answer their questions and teach them the history and the history of women." I would say you are very good parents. We are trying. We're not perfect, but we're not that bad either. title: Ayo Edebiri, Pedro Almodóvar, and More Celebrate the Loewe Foundation Craft Prize in Madrid
article_text: Late last month, the Loewe Foundation Craft Prize ceremony returned home to Madrid, Spain. During a cocktail and tapas hour in the Thyssen-Bornemisza National Museum’s courtyard, finalists and their guests mingled with the new creative directors of Loewe,Jack McColloughandLazaro Hernandez,and jury members includingFrida Escobedo,the architect, essayist, and visionary behind the new Tang Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City; andAbraham Thomas,the curator of modern architecture, design, and decorative arts at The Met. Since its inception in 2016, the Loewe Foundation Craft Prize, which was envisioned by the brand’s former creative directorJonathan Anderson,has celebrated artistic merit and newness in modern craftsmanship. The label encourages anyone over 18 working in a craft-based profession to apply and compete for a prize of 50,000 euros, with two special mentions each receiving 25,000 euros. According to Loewe, a panel of experts decides upon the winner based on their “originality, clear artistic vision and merit, precise execution, material excellence, innovative value, and a distinct authorial mark.” A few famous friends of Loewe also made appearances at the award ceremony.Ayo Edebiri,Lesley Manville,andMurray Bartlettwere seen chatting among attendees, enjoying the perfect weather and awaiting the announcement of the winner. Elsewhere, filmmakerPedro Almodóvarwas seen sporting a fun pair of Loewe glasses while being escorted through the crowd and gesturing to those that expressed their love of his films. During the festivities, attendees were encouraged to step inside the Thyssen-Bornemisza National Museum to preview the 30 finalists’ creations. Many of the artisans proudly stood next to their work, answering questions about the processes they used and what inspired them to submit their pieces for the Loewe Foundation Craft Prize. Nifemi Marcus-Bello of Nigeria received a special mention for his piece titled “TM Bench with Bowl." As the ceremony began, guests quieted down and shifted their focus to the podium. One of the special mentions was presented toNifemi Marcus-Belloof Nigeria for his piece titled “TM Bench With Bowl.” During the private viewing, he said he initially didn’t understand why people gravitated toward his submission piece until he placed it in his own home. It was then he had his own aha moment. The second special mention was presented byMeg Ryanto StudioSumakshi Singhfrom India forher piece “Monument.”Singh used a thread made of copper and nylon on a water-soluble backing to create a reimagining of a 12th-century historic colonnade in the Qutab Minar complex in Delhi. Sheila Loeweand Almodóvar presented the night’s top award with a beautifully witty dance between Almodóvar’s Spanish and an English translation by Loewe. Almodóvar movingly stated that “the artists in the exhibition represent a continued need to remain curious. I urge you all to slow down and spend time with the works.” He then graciously announced the winner, Japanese sculptorKunimasa Aoki,for his piece “Realm of Living Things 19.” Aoki, who is also a high school design teacher in Japan, said his terra-cotta piece, which uses an ancestral technique that distorts the clay under pressure, said it took three months to complete. When accepting the award, Aoki thanked his fellow participants and said they gave him strength to do more work in the future. When asked what inspires him, Aoki joked that “I am very boring,” before revealing that he loves motorbikes as well as the filmsEasy RiderandMad Max. This story has been updated. title: Queen Máxima of the Netherlands Sparkles In Rubies Dating Back to 1888 During State Visit
article_text: On Wednesday evening, the President of the Czech Republic hosted a gala dinner forKing Willem-AlexanderandQueen Máximaof the Netherlands. For the occasion, Máxima wore a look by Dutch designerJan Taminiau, rewearing a one-sleeved batwing dress in dark red that she has worn in other important appointments. The silk dress features embroidered beading all around its edge. Queen Máxima and King Willem-Alexander The frock was the perfect companion to the Mellerio ruby set that the queen wore, almost in its entirety. With the exception of the brooch, the earrings and the bodice jewel, Máxima wore the three-pronged tiara, the choker and the diamond and ruby bracelet that complete this set, which was a gift from King William III to Queen consort Emma at Christmas 1888. The monarch commissioned the design from one of the most famous French jewelry firms of the time: Mellerio dits Meller. Queen Máxima The queen has worn the pieces on many occasions and for official portraits. She has chosen it for a number of weddings, birthdays and gala banquets, and it also seems to be special forPrincess Amalia, who wore the tiara last Aprilfor the first time in an official capacity. The portrait of that moment was published on the occasion of the 18th birthday of the princess, highlightingAmalia's love for tiaras. Queen Maxima completed her look with diamond and ruby flower-shaped earrings, another diamond bracelet and the metropolitan insignia handbag with golden crystals by Carolina Herrera. On Thursday, the Queen will continue her solo engagements in Prague before returning to the Netherlands at the end of the day. King Willem-Alexander has had to return a day earlier than planned after the unexpected collapse of the government this week. title: MSNBC’s Nicolle Wallace on Her New Podcast, Trump’s “Undemocratic” Antics, and How the GOP Lost Its Way
article_text: The MSNBC control room in 30 Rock was bustling on Wednesday afternoon, with monitors galore and more than a dozen production staffers manning the cable-news ship. ButNicolle Wallacewouldn’t be needing the traditional cable-news setup for that day’s recording of her new podcast,The Best People. I met Wallace briefly before the taping, which was featuring the brothers behind MeidasTouch, the independent, pro-democracy media network whose podcast briefly unseatedJoe Rogan’s on the charts, a fact I overheard someone mention as we headed toward the studio. While the audio format is a new endeavor for Wallace, who will continue to tape more content for the recently launched series, this was notBen,Brett,andJordy Meiselas’s first rodeo. When Wallace walked into the room, flanked by a pared-down production team, the trio was already waiting for her onscreen, each in their own individual studio with mics primed. Immediately, Wallace sat down, putting on her red-rimmed glasses and headphones, and got to work, asking the brothers how they were able to distill complex political news into digestible commentary and grow their audience in the process. It was a fitting booking for Wallace in terms of political perspective—with both MSNBC and MeidasTouch appealing to the anti-Trump resistance—but also, perhaps, a savvy one, as the latter wields a deeply engaged community dubbed theMeidas Mighty, whose members will surely travel over to MSNBC’s YouTube channel to catch the conversation.The MeidasTouch Podcastis among themost popularpolitics shows on YouTube, a platform MSNBC is increasingly turning to; it first did so quietly, withWhy Is This Happening? The Chris Hayes Podcast,and as of Thursday, the first two episodes of Wallace’s podcast areavailabletowatch. The Best People,which debuted at number one on the Apple Podcasts charts after launching Monday, marks Wallace’s first foray into the podcast space, and its content varies significantly from that of her two-hour block on weekdays forDeadline: White House,on which she has conducted interviews with political leaders such asformer presidentJoe Biden,House minority leaderHakeem Jeffries,andMichigan governorGretchen Whitmer,as well as formerFBIdirectorJames Comey.Guests from all industries are featured on the first season of the new podcast, including actorsJason Bateman, Sarah Jessica Parker,andJeff Daniels;music producerJimmy Jam;Milwaukee Bucks coachDoc Rivers;and media figuresRachel MaddowandKara Swisher. In an interview, Wallace acknowledged that the podcast lineup is less explicitly political than her typical MSNBC guest list, though those coming on, in addition to being “insanely and wildly accomplished,” are also “interested in talking about the moment and the world around us.” As a former White House communications chief underGeorge W. Bushand senior adviser for John McCain’s 2008 presidential campaign, Wallace hasn’t identified with the GOP since Trump came on the scene, voting forHillary Clintonin 2016, Biden in 2020, andKamala Harrisin 2024. “The Republican Party broke my heart the first time,” she tells me. “I don’t expect anything from them, but even expecting nothing, I’m embarrassed for them that they’ve relinquished so much authority,” Wallace adds, referring to congressional Republicans’ unwillingness to push back on Trump’s executive overreaches. “Trump isn’t acting in a way that is Republican,” Wallace says. “He’s acting in a way, in my view, that is undemocratic.” Our full conversation, which has been edited for length and clarity, is below. Vanity Fair:I would love to hear in your own words what this podcast aims to be and how the format and content might differ from your on-air work. Nicolle Wallace:First of all,The Best Peopleis our effort to repossess or reappropriate Donald Trump’s pledge to have “all the best people” in his first term. That clearly wasn’t a term being used to describe the folks in the second term, so we thought we’d have fun with it, with people who actually are legitimately, and objectively, the very best people, certainly that I have come across in my career and life. There’s such a range of guests in this first season, from people like Jason Bateman to Kara Swisher and, even from your own network, Rachel Maddow. I’m curious what sort of through line, if any, you saw in their stories? All of them are so engaged in the world in which we live. Sarah Jessica Parker is so deeply focused on public libraries and worried about what will happen if we have to go without any of them or if their hours are cut. Jason Bateman is so incredibly astute about this political moment and the need to bring everybody into the conversation, to get beyond a moment where politics is so divided. The through line, obviously, is that they’re all insanely and wildly accomplished. That I even know all of them is mind-blowing to me. But if there’s a through line in the conversations themselves, it’s that not one of them found it easy to talk about themselves. They were much more interested in talking about the moment and the world around us. Several of your guests are from the world of entertainment. What are your thoughts on the role of pop culture in shaping political society today? I think it’s from the other way around. If you look at the history of any political movement, it never comes from Washington. It never comes from politics. It comes from culture. You look at Donald Trump’s nod to the manosphere, that was really a nod to culture and the power of culture. I don’t think any of these people would say that they’re going to move politics, but I think all these people care so deeply about different policy issues. Their voice and their role in shaping the culture is probably more significant than any of them think. This is a podcast that’s a little less focused on the more typically political aspects of your job. Do you see this content as an escape from the news or possibly a supplement to it? What I found was, with Sarah Jessica, for example, we sat down and just dove right into the news of the day. We talked about some of these policies. And I was the one who said, “I got to screenAnd Just Like That…” I would get, like, half an answer out of her, and then she’d want to go right back into the broader world in which we live, or the sort of things that our children will confront. Jeff Daniels was the same. He just wrapped up a really neat project in which he plays[Ronald] Reagan.I was interested in talking to him about his new projects and other things, and he plays the guitar for me in the episode. But he, too, had his mind on this moment. What it is is maybe just more in proportion to how people think about politics in their own lives. I don’t know that people will feel like they’re devoid of politics. They certainly aren’t. There was no prescription or structure about how much politics we would talk about, but they are certainly people who are very astute and smart about our politics, that obviously have accomplishments and credibility in broader fields. I wanted to turn to the news of the day and Trump’s second administration. Have you felt any change in the tone or tempo of the political news cycle under his second term? It’s whatever you make of it. We at the show have made a decision to try to slow it down. The freneticism that we brought to the first term was just so dizzying. So we made a decision as a show—instead of trying to do 20 stories in two hours, we try to do maybe four. The pace is what it always is with Trump. My sense after he won was that we should try different things, and we’ve felt like our audience has really stayed with us. I’ve always said this—and this became really true during the pandemic—we have a monogamous relationship with the viewer. I’m curious to hear your thoughts on Trump’s attacks on press freedom. Should the media at large be concerned? We should always do our jobs concerned. The power of the things that we say and do is so great that we should always be cognizant and make sure that we have all of our facts straight. I think that the way Trump is governing in the second term makes it a lot easier, because it’s all out in the open. In the first term, we relied so much on investigative journalism and investigative stories, and then the second term, so much of it is just out in the open. That may end up being a symptom of Trump’s real or perceived political strength. It may be a symptom of him being a lame duck. He’s not running again. He feels like he has mastered the job. I don’t know why that is, but the seeming corruption of the pardon process or the rule of law is all happening in plain sight. In terms of press freedoms, if you look at countries that move toward an autocracy, there is intimidation, there are lawsuits, there are things that start to happen. We’re obviously watching for those things and concerned about them, but I think our focus day-to-day is on covering the things that happen in full view and holding up a mirror to them. We’re trying to deepen our understanding of why they’re happening and how they differ, not just from past presidents, but the past Trump administration. We have a lot of security from the folks that we work for, having our backs and worrying about running the company, so that we can cover the news. It is obviously a live wire and a dynamic thing that anyone who says they’re not concerned about it or watching it, I’m not sure would be telling you the truth. It’s something Trump talked about enough, going back to his first term and describing the press as the enemy of the people, that we have to take him literally and seriously. I wanted to go back to something you just said about it possibly being a symptom of Trump being a lame duck in a sense, but at the same time, all this is happening in plain sight. He’s been unwilling to shut down rumors about running for a third term, even though that’s not constitutionally plausible. How are you looking at that, if at all? I haven’t covered that yet. I’ve tried to take a one-foot-in-front-of-the-other approach to the second term. I think it’s important to acknowledge that everything is possible. We’ve never before elected someone convicted of 34 felonies. So it is certainly plausible that he does that. And you’re right, he has flirted with it publicly. But I think that getting ahead of the story is how you lose that connection with your own audience. What people can take in immediately is what has already happened, the news that is happening right in front of us. So we’ve stayed more focused on the news of the day. But I think that norm busting and waving something in front of us that is unconstitutional flagrantly delights him, and it is obviously an important thing to keep an eye on. Given your experience prior to journalism, as a former White House communications director for a Republican president, I’m curious how you’re reflecting on the Republican Party of today? The Republican Party broke my heart the first time. It’s sort of like, fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me. I don’t expect anything from them, but even expecting nothing, I’m embarrassed for them that they’ve relinquished so much authority. You don’t have to make Trump mad to say, “Hey, Congress has a role here. We get to decide if your nominees are qualified to run such venerable institutions like the Pentagon and the FBI.” That they don’t seem to be interested in doing the normal functions of that branch is amazing to me, but not surprising. What would you say to other former Republicans or those more traditional Republicans who are struggling with their place in the current political landscape? I never thought there were enough “Never Trump” Republicans to be a meaningful voting bloc. I think that the better function is to articulate how unconservative all these things are. Trump isn’t acting in a way that is Republican. He’s acting in a way, in my view, that is undemocratic. It’s an interesting moment, and I think the oldest rules of politics apply here–it’s the economy, stupid. If Trump’s tariffs do what Trump has said they will do—if they make it very expensive for people to purchase things at places like Walmart and Target, which have already said they’re going to raise their prices—then it’ll be interesting to see if that changes or erodes any of his public support. It’s already happening in the polls, but we’ll see how that translates and if that translates into any courage for Republicans in Congress who see their constituents hurting. On the other side, what do you make of the Democrats’ messaging strategy in response? Is it meeting this moment? I think there are some extraordinary messengers. I see the things thatChris Murphyputs out almost instantly, and he’s doing them on social media. He’s doing them on the floor of the Senate. He’s doing it in interviews. I saw whatCory Bookerdid, which was botha powerful messageand a sort of unforgettable tactic, the filibuster. I was a Republican, so I understand the muscle memory and the reflexes and history of the Republican Party. I have never been a Democrat. I voted for three Democrats for president since Trump came on the scene, but I’ve never been a Democrat, so I try to refrain from too much analysis. I think that the recklessness with which Trump is treating the economy, and the indifference to how people will feel about flagrant self-enrichment, feel like opportunities for Democrats. But we’ll see if Democrats run with that as a political message. What does your media diet look like? My husband,[Michael Schmidt], is obviously atTheNew York Times,so I have a real affinity for theTimes.I consume a lot ofNew York Timeslive blogs. I read everything thatThe Atlanticputs out. I’m in awe of the depth and the beauty of their pieces. I watched probably most or all of Rachel [Maddow’s] 100 days. I have a 13-year-old and a one-year-old, so I don’t get a lot of the evening diet because I’m doing homework or bath or bed, but I try to watch as much ofMorning Joeas I can before my house wakes up and takes off. The one big difference? I quit X. I don’t see any of the social media stuff. I don’t see what Trump posts. I don’t see what[Elon] Muskposts. And that’s a problem, because we have to cover it. That’s where my big blind spot is. My team mostly flags stuff for me. title: Intruder Arrested on the Grounds of Windsor Castle
article_text: On Sunday, June 1, at around 1 p.m.,the apparent calm of Windsorwas suddenly disturbed by an incident the Crown would have preferred to avoid. A man in his 30s, reportedly believed to have been under the influence of Class A drugs (which include heroin, methadone, methamphetamine, cocaine, ecstasy, and hallucinogens such as LSD), managed to cross the protected boundaries of the royal estate. Fortunately, he did not reach the central, ultra-secure part of the castle. The man was intercepted near Town Gate (a peripheral access point) by forces from the Royal and Specialist Protection Command, the royal family’s bodyguard service in charge of security at royal sites. The man was quickly neutralized and handed over to Thames Valley Police. He was arrested on suspicion of trespass on a protected site and possession of drugs, before being released on bail pending further investigation. According to initial investigations, he did not appear to have any malicious intent. The other dimension of this case concerns the immediate proximity of the intrusion to Adelaide Cottage. Located southeast of Windsor Castle, the home was gifted byQueen Elizabeth IItoPrince WilliamandKate Middletonafter she promised it toMeghan MarkleandPrince Harryin 2018. It is the current residence of the couple of Wales and their three children,PrinceGeorge,PrincessCharlotte,andPrince Louis.Although their presence at the scene has not been confirmed, their schedule did not indicate any official travel that day. In other words, the family could very well have been just a stone’s throw away from the intruder. This is not the first time that the symbol of the British monarchy has been breached. Last October,masked burglars broke into a farm building on the estate, making off with two vehicles. In 2021a man armed with a crossbowwas arrested on the castle grounds; when he was approached by police, the suspect voiced his intention to assassinate the queen. In the same year, another individual climbed over fences andmade it ontothe palace grounds twice. This story has been updated. title: Dakota Johnson and Chris Martin Reportedly Break Up for Real This Time
article_text: The romance betweenDakota JohnsonandChris Martinhas reportedly come to an end. Sources tellPeoplemagazine that the actor and the Coldplay musician, who got together in 2017, have parted after almost eight years in an on-again, off-again relationship. “It feels final this time,” one source told the publication. TheFifty Shades of Greystar and the singer were spottedwalking in Malibutogether just a few weeks ago. InJanuary, they were photographed hand in hand in India during Coldplay’s tour. Through her relationship with Martin, Johnson also built a beautiful bond withApple MartinandMoses Martin,the children Martin shares with ex-wifeGwyneth Paltrow.Though she and Martin were not married, Johnson referred to Apple and Moses as her stepchildren in a 2024 interview withBustle.“I love those kids like my life depends on it. With all my heart,” she said. “I grew up in a family that was so big, and I just believe in the saying ‘Blood is thicker than water.’ The actual saying is ‘The blood of the covenant is thicker than the water of the womb,’ which means that the connections with people you choose are more solid than the connections to the people you’re actually born to.” Johnson also spoke about her unique blended family in a2022Vanity Faircover story. “Maybe I think about relationships like that differently because I grew up in my family,” she said. “We were all cool. Obviously, there were times where it was not cool, but I experienced that, so I don’t want that in my life. I don’t want any kids to experience anything like that. It’s better to be kind, and it’s also really nice that everybody actually really loves each other and has each other’s backs.” The Coldplay singer was first spotted with theFifty Shades of Greystar in October 2017. The following year, the two made their first public appearance together during a fashion show for designerStella McCartney.In March 2024—after several apparent breakups and reunions—the pair revealed that they were officiallyengaged. A few months later, however, there was talk of another estrangement, whichtheDaily Mailclaimedwas caused by irreconcilable work schedules. A spokesperson for the actor, however,denied the news, giving assurance that the two were still together and happy. “Their relationship works because they are both very independent and actually have lives outside of their relationship too. It’s like every time they are not spotted together for a while, there are breakup rumors,” a sourcetoldPeopleat the time. “Sure, they’ve had issues and taken breaks in the past, but things are great now. They both love their careers. They are balancing things the best they can.” Original story inVFItalia.

title: It’s Been 38 Years Since a Black Playwright Won Best Play at the Tonys. Branden Jacobs-Jenkins Could Change That.
article_text: “I’m so tired” are the first words that playwrightBranden Jacobs-Jenkinsutters when he gets on the phone. There’s good reason for that: Almost one year after winning the Tony Award for best revival of a play for his searing white Southern family drama,Appropriate,Jacobs-Jenkins is getting ready forthe Tony Awards 2025, where he’s nominated for best play forPurpose,which follows a politically prominent Black family in Chicago on one unforgettable evening. In a year stacked with buzzy plays likeCole Escola’s smash hit,Oh, Mary!,and theSadie Sink–ledJohn Proctor Is the Villain,Purposehas perhaps emerged as the leader of the pack, earning the Pulitzer Prize for drama and taking home best play at the Drama Desk Awards. If Jacobs-Jenkins does emerge victorious, he’ll be the first Black playwright to win the Tony for best play since August Wilson took home the trophy in 1987 forFences.The absurdity isn’t lost on Jacobs-Jenkins, especially when considering how many Black playwrights are thriving in American theater at the moment. “It’s likeTarell [Alvin McCraney],Aleshea [Harris],Dominique [Morisseau], Suzan-Lori [Parks],” he says, rattling off his Black playwright peers. “Lynn Nottagestill hasn’t won a Tony.” While the Tonys may not have taken notice, other awards bodies have. “I think 8 of the last 10 Pulitzers are Black writers,” he adds. “That says a lot about where American drama is. Full stop.” (He’s close: It’s seven.) In conversation withVanity Fair,Jacobs-Jenkins says he’s feeling “crazy” heading into his second Tony ceremony as a nominated playwright. “I didn’t really understand how triggered I would be by doing it right back-to-back,” he says. “It’s been really fun and in some ways really relaxing, but it’s a lot of energy and a lot of expectation.” Oh, and there’s another reason Jacobs-Jenkins is more than a little exhausted. “I also have a three-month-old child at home,” he says nonchalantly. “You wake up twice in the middle of the night to feed, and it’s just crazy. It’s just too much.” Luckily, adding a new member to his family—he and his husband, actor and cabaret artistCheo Bourne,also have a four-year-old daughter,Indigo,at home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn—has helped keep the roller coaster of his last year in perspective. “She’s a brand-new person. It’s wild,” he says. “She don’t care. She don’t know what any of this is. But hopefully one day she’ll be like, ‘I’m so glad this was happening while I was learning how to poop or whatever.’” While juggling a newborn baby and a newborn play can be tough, Jacobs-Jenkins is filled with gratitude. “I’m happy,” he says. “I’m overwhelmed and grateful and all those positive things too.” This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity. Vanity Fair:Last year you won best revival of a play forAppropriate,which you had written 10 years prior. How does this year compare to last year? Branden Jacobs-Jenkins:​​The stakes were lower. Last year our show opened a little earlier. Once the nominations came out, I was like, Oh, okay. I had little time. I’d gone on a little vacation. This year we opened a little bit later. I feel like we had no time to really recover. Suddenly, we were being invited to all these lovely things. Last year it was decided that we were a revival, and that race was just a different race. It was a smaller category. The other lovely people were dead [laughs]. If you’d asked me a year ago ifPurposewas going to be on Broadway, I would’ve been like, “No, of course not.” So I’m as shocked as anybody. The way the audiences are responding has been really special. The company itself feels like a little family. So it’s just been a very sweet, fun, happy little ragtag group of people. And that’s been really special too. Purposestarted at Steppenwolf Theatre in Chicago. Can you talk to me a bit about the development process? There really aren’t that many storied acting ensembles left in the world. It’s one of our only ones. They contacted me almost 10 years ago now and said, “We want to talk about you.” I thought they were talking about doing one of my plays, likeAppropriateor something. It was an offer for this commission, and they were very specific. That era was still feeling its oats with theTracy Lettsof it all, theBruce Norrisof it all. They’re like, “The only requirement is that you have to write for our members of our ensemble, and our house style is muscular realism.” That’s the phrase they used. I don’t think they really say that anymore. I was like, “Okay, I love a challenge.” I remember going on their website and scrolling through their ensemble and zeroing in on three people who are actually still in the show:Glenn Davis,Alana Arenas,andJon Michael Hill,who at that time were young upstarts in the company. Ten years later, Glenn is literally the artistic director. That was the very beginning, the seeds of it. All I knew was I wanted to write a family drama with them, and then they were going to play siblings. As the idea evolved, I liked the idea of Alana as a sister-in-law more, married to Glenn. That’s how it started. Honestly, it was pure playing around that got us to where we got to. It really grew quite organically out of that collaboration. I wish I could pretend I had a whole play and idea when I sat down to write this, but the story really did find itself. And honestly—no one talks about this—but 95% of plays, that’s how it really works. LaTanya Richardson Jackson, Jon Michael Hill, Glenn Davis, and Alana Areneas inPurpose. As a writer, that’s nice to hear, because you think of divine inspiration striking someone and it all comes out in a day, and that’s actually not how it works. I think it’s calledplayfor a reason. I think it really does resemble play on a playground with your friends. It’s my job to design the game. But everybody’s got their own special powers and their own interests in what they want to play, and I was interested in giving them things that would challenge them. I didn’t want anyone to play something they played before. Purposeis loosely based on the family of civil rights icon Jesse Jackson, and explores the idea of a legacy and the weight of carrying that legacy in a Black family. It’s clearly a lot of pressure. Not everyone can be Jesse Jackson. Nor should everyone need to be. Can you imagine the stress it would be if we all had to be Jesse Jackson? [Laughs] I grew up adjacent to this in DC. There were tons of these folks in my life, and it was a lot of work. In some ways people thought of it as battle. They were going to war. War has costs ultimately, and a lot of those costs are borne by the family. You’re a prolific playwright who’s written a bunch of more avant-garde work likeAn Octoroon,The Comeuppance,andGloria.Your first two Broadway plays,AppropriateandPurpose,are more traditional, big family, kitchen-sink dramas. What is it like for you to find major success in this specific theater niche? It’s so funny, right?Purposewas definitely conceived in relationship to my experience withAppropriate.When I got the commission, it was soon afterAppropriate’s initial wave of premieres. I wrote a lot of this while in rehearsals forAppropriatelast year. I thought a lot about it. I find that the family drama—as weird and contrived and artificial, in some ways, as melodrama or a thriller—for whatever reason, it really touches people more broadly because we all have families. The story we tell ourselves as a member of a family is the oldest story we have of ourselves ultimately. Our earliest memories are of being someone’s child, and maybe someone’s brother and sister, before we discovered what we wanted to do in the world I honestly think I can write family dramas till I die. I really do. I love people talking about their families. I love talking about my family. America’s favorite pastime is gossiping about families and analyzing people based on their families. How do you navigate switching between more avant-garde work and more traditional work? It has been really interesting. My two experiences of Broadway have been these exact forms. I would say the majority of folks, up until maybe recently, would’ve known me for my playAn Octoroon,which is maybe one of the most wild and out-there of my plays. Yeah. I don’t feel like a different Branden when I sit down and write these things. They all require the same kind of work. I guess they just hit differently or whatever. I live inside the experience of writing them. For me, they’re all connected in strange, underground ways. But as flowers, they manifest different for people. [Laughs] They’re all, to me, tied to a deep interest in history. What is Americanness, and how is human psychology, and therefore human relationships, shaped by historical forces? Those are always the themes. They just come out looking different. Do people assume that there’s more of you inPurpose,because it’s about a Black family, thanAppropriate,which is about a white family? Literally, last night someone was like, “So are you Naz?” And I’m like, “No, I’m not an asexual nature photographer in a political family.” [Laughs] It’s insane. The truth is, most storytellers would say that you’re in every single character on some level. That character is just observations you made in your life. If there’s a character [inPurpose] my biography cues closest to, it’s probably the character of Aziza, whichKara Youngplays. But again, I’m not a queer woman having a baby on my own, you know what I mean? It’s just such a funny thing. The plays I’ve written up until now have been very intentionally not biographical in a way that I think has made people crave something like that for me…. I feel people projecting that need onto this, which is fine. Whatever gets people in seats and connected. [Purpose] is a world I think I probably know more intimately, just having grown up where I grew up, when I grew up. No one asks me who I am inAppropriate.My friends know. Do you still go and watchPurpose? Do you lurk in the theater? Here’s the dirty secret: I went on paternity leave the minute we opened. I actually have not seen the show since the opening night. I’m going back for the first time on Friday. I think I’m also a little bit suspicious. I don’t like to be in the room when people are in the room who matter. The Tony voters begin to come, and I don’t want to be in the room. I feel like people are watching me, even if they’re not. Back when I was an emerging writer, no one cared about me. To some extent, people still don’t care about me. But sometimes now people want to come up and talk to me and tell me their thoughts, and I’m just not there for it. Do you read reviews? Well, I have a rule. I read them six months after it’s closed, just to not get hurt. But honestly, the truth is, you know what the reviews are because your friends treat you differently. [Laughs] You just know. It is so embarrassing too. If you have really rave reviews, everyone’s texting you the next day. If you don’t, your closest friends are calling you, being like…“How are you?” [Laughs] Have you seen the other shows? I feel like this is a really strong year for theater, specifically new plays. Oh yeah. Last year was also a strong year for plays. What’s cool about this year’s plays is that everything is so different. If you think aboutOh, Mary!versus this versusJohn ProctorversusEnglish,things could not be more different. Last year they were saying, “It’s a good time for plays,” and I think that’s true. Plays are having a comeback. I don’t know why. Maybe because they’re cheaper to do and producers don’t want to spend money. I don’t know. But no skin off my back. I really think that in my cohort, at least, there’s been just an incredible bumper crop of writers for the theater, definitely compared to folks maybe a generation ahead of us. So I feel like everyone’s coming of age, and next year a lot of my friends are going to be transferring, some of them for the first time, to Broadway. I feel very lucky to be making theater in this moment. A Black playwright hasn’t won best play at the Tony Awards since August Wilson won in 1987. What are your thoughts about that? Somebody just pointed that out to me, and I’m like, That can’t possibly be true. That can’t possibly be true, but I guess it is true. I was three years old. I have a four-year-old. I just find that to be truly insane. There’ve been a lot of great folks nominated. The truth is, the last two women to win this prize were both namedYasmina Reza.There’s questions to ask. It’s an honor to be nominated, and the real reward is the audience. Tony Sunday is approaching. How are you feeling about it? No one really writes plays, I don’t think, to win Tony Awards. But it’s a nice thing that happens. There’s just nerves. It means so much to people. Really, really, really, for me, it’s about the actors who I think did an incredible amount of work. I’m really thinking about them going into Sunday, and, I don’t know, my first Tony Awards I accidentally watched when I was 13 years old. It was the onewhere Elaine Stritch won, and I remember her getting cut off by the camera in this vicious way. I remember thinking, Oh, that’s the center of the universe up there. It’s so weird to be sitting in that audience now and wondering who is accidentally watching this in some sad bedroom in DC. It was the beginning of me being like, I need to move to New York. And here I am, having made this life here, and I’m just so grateful. title: Molly Gordon’s So Much More Than The Bear’s Dream Girl
article_text: “I’ve never been in something that people watch,” says Molly Gordon, “which is a very different experience.” She’s talking about her breakout turn in the bittersweetEmmy favoriteThe Bearand underselling her résumé a little: Gordon has been onRamyandAnimal Kingdom,as well as indie movies likeBooksmart.But it’s true that playing the woman trying to get into the locked freezer of Carmy’s heart has put a more intense spotlight on Gordon. Jeremy Allen White’s protagonist “is a character that people feel so protective over, and it’s been kind of controversial to bring a romantic element into the show,” she says. “That’s been at times annoying, fascinating, and interesting—just to be a part of something that people have opinions on.” She’ll have to get used to it, because it’s going to be a very Molly Gordon summer.The Bear’sfourth seasonwill debut on June 25, and her Sundance road trip movieOh, Hi!hits theaters on July 25. InOh, Hi!she plays a woman who goes on a romantic weekend getaway with her boyfriend (Logan Lerman) but soon discovers that he isn’t as serious about the relationship as she is. Instead of moving on from that ego hit, she decides she’s going to hold him captive and convince him that she’s actually the right girl for him. Gordon worked with writer-director Sophie Brooks on the story for the charmingly odd dark comedy, which takes a long, painful look at the modern dating landscape. “With apps, it’s just such a hard time to date in our modern age, and we’ve had a communication breakdown between sexes,” Gordon says. “We just wanted to make something that is about how hard it is to just be honest about how you feel about someone.” Gordon says the role of Iris is based on herself if she were just “five percent crazier.” But she also grounds the character enough that the audience can still root for her, even when she’s making some pretty lamentable choices. It was an opportunity to portray the sort of intense character Gordon is always hunting around for. “We don’t really get to be crazy,” she says. “There’s just still not that many great female characters out there—the kind of wild characters usually played by men.” BeforeThe Bear,Gordon was probably best known for cowriting, codirecting, and starring inTheater Camp,acritically acclaimed2023 comedy that won a Special Jury Award at Sundance. Shewrote the scriptwith her friends Ben Platt, Noah Galvin, and Nick Lieberman (she and Platt have known each other since they were three years old); it’s set at the titular location and inspired by their own experiences as theater nerds. Gordon surprised even herself when raised her hand to codirect the film with Lieberman. She’d always wanted to direct but wasn’t sure it was in the cards for her. “It was something I had quieted for so many years, because the statistics are so insane for women,” she says. Indeed, it’s bleak: As of 2024, women accounted for just 16 percent of directors working on the US’s 250 highest-grossing domestic releases. “I just still feel like I struggle with taking up space and just living authentically in that I’m the leader. It’s just still hard for me sometimes to fully own that,” says Gordon. Yet this summer she will start shooting her solo directorial debut,Peaked,an A24 high school reunion comedy she also cowrote and will star in. “I feel lucky that I can create things, because what’s so hard with acting is that you have to wait for someone to go, ‘Here, you can be creative today,’ ” she says. “With writing, every day you can wake up and have agency over your own creativity in your own life.” A Los Angeles native, Gordon learned about storytelling from her parents, director Bryan Gordon and writer-director Jessie Nelson. “My parents were always breaking story”—i.e., plotting out movies and TV shows—“or trying to turn shitty things that happened to them into a funny idea around the dinner table,” she says. She’s aware that industry outsiders think second-generation writers and actors have an advantage because of their access, and she doesn’t disagree, though she thinks there’s more nuance to it: “It’s access and all these things, but it’s also just realizing how inconsistent and hard it is.” Gordon decided to move across the country to enroll at NYU but only lasted a few weeks. She made a PowerPoint presentation to convince her parents to let her leave school and stay in New York to pursue an acting career. It worked: “I was really brave when I was 18. I don’t think I’ll ever be as cool as I was then, because I had no friends and took classes with 50-year-olds.” It would take a few years of acting classes and restaurant work for her to gain any momentum, and there were lots of hurdles along the way. At one point, an agent she met with told Gordon to her face that acting wasn’t the right career for her. “Which was totally fair,” she says now. “I wasn’t ready.” When she’d run into acquaintances from home, there’d often be an awkward conversation about what she’d been up to since dropping out of college. “I feel like people looked down on me a bit. I seemed a little lost, which I was. But I kind of needed to be in that moment.” Finally, the roles started to come. She booked the TNT seriesAnimal Kingdom,then got to work with Melissa McCarthy in the 2018 comedyLife of the PartyandOlivia Wilde inBooksmart.She was finally working on projects that aligned with her tastes—and she made friends who were doing the same thing. Gordon’s social circle now includes fellow rising stars Ayo Edebiri and Rachel Sennott. “I actually can’t imagine that I would have a career without those girls,” she says. “I don’t really have any doctor friends—I’m kind of friends with this circus. We’re all insane.” Gordon metThe Bearcreator Christopher Storer during her three-episode stint onRamy,which Storer also directed and executive-produced. She signed onto his new show knowing only that she’d play a doctor; it wasn’t until later that Gordon realized Claire Dunlap, a.k.a. “Claire Bear,” was Carmy’s love interest, his childhood sweetheart who comes back into his life after a chance run-in at the grocery store. “I’m always ‘the friend,’ ” she says. “I’ve never played the romantic person. I was like, ‘Whoa, this is going to be a different experience.’ ” Her role gets bigger in the fourth season ofThe Bear,which she says will explore Carmy’s struggle to add some life to his work-life balance. It’s a topic that’s been weighing on her as well. Last fall, Gordon found herself at the center of tabloid speculation when photos emerged of her and White cozying up and kissing off-set. She sidesteps the topic gracefully, saying, “With the internet, I just think—I even see it in myself as a fan of things—we’re just a more judgmental society.” Gordon’s role onThe Bearis much more dramatic than she’s accustomed to; it speaks to her hopes for the future—that she won’t be stuck playing in her comedy ball pit. Yes, she loves projects with “a little bit of cheekiness,” but she’s drawn to darker material too. “It’s funny, women in comedy get kind of put in a box,” she says. “I’d love to do drama—I could do some drugs in a basement. Let’s go.” Her acting success has only buoyed her directing ambitions. There’sPeaked;she’s also cowriting a new take on the 1987 comedyOutrageous Fortunefor Searchlight. “I don’t care about being the lead in something,” she says. “I want to work with people that I admire, and that feels like more of the key to longevity for me in this career than trying to make it a name for myself as an actress.” HAIR, JUNYA NAKASHIMA; MAKEUP, MAKI RYOKE; MANICURE, ELINA OGAWA; TAILOR, JEN HEBNER; SET DESIGN, COLIN PHELAN. title: Banned substance found in water supply of 2 Hong Kong housing estates
article_text: Black particles in supply at two Fanling estates are mainly bitumen, government says, while stressing the water is safe to drink Black particles found in the freshwater supply at two public housing estates are mainly bitumen, authorities have said, while stressing that the water is safe to drink. Director of Water Supplies Roger Wong Yan-lok sought to reassure the public on Thursday after government tests showed the presence of the substance, which is banned from use in pipes, in most of the 126 samples collected from each of the blocks in Queens Hill Estate and Shan Lai Court, both in Fanling. “Bitumen is insoluble in water and is not harmful to humans,” he said. Wong added that experts commissioned by the Water Supplies Department five years ago did not find any toxic substances in three litres of hot water boiled with 10 grams of bitumen. “Even if residents drink water containing bitumen, there is no need to worry,” he said. Residents at the two public rental and subsidised estates first reported the presence of black particles in their drinking water on Friday last week, prompting some to buy bottled water as speculation mounted over the source of the mysterious dark specks.
